chapter.p: 1. And after the death of Shaul, Dovid returned from defeating Amoleik. Dovid dwelled in Tziklog for two days.
2. On the third day behold a man came from the camp, from Shaul’s people. His clothes were torn and dirt was on his head. And when he came to Dovid, he fell to the ground and prostrated himself.
3. Dovid said to him, “From where are you coming?” The man replied to him, “I have escaped from the Yisroelite camp.”
4. Dovid said to him, “What happened, please tell me?” The man replied, “The people fled from the war. In addition, many of the people fell and died. And Shaul and his son Yohonoson also died.”
5. Dovid said to the young man who was informing him, “How do you know that Shaul and his son Yohonoson have died?”
6. The young man who was informing him replied, I happened by chance upon Mount Gilboa and there was Shaul impaled upon his spear. Presently, the chariots and horsemen were coming close to him.
7. He turned around and saw me and he called to me, I said, ‘Here I am.’
8. He said to me, ‘Who are you?’ I replied to him, ‘I am an Amoleikite.’
9. He said to me, ‘Stand over me and kill me—because I am gripped with convulsions—while I am still alive.’

10. I stood over him and killed him because I knew he would not live after his fall. I took the crown that was upon his head and the bracelet that was on his arm and I have brought them here to my master.”
11. Dovid took hold of his clothes and ripped them as did all the men that were with him.
12. The eulogized, they cried and they fasted until the evening over Shaul, and over his son Yohonoson, over the people of Adonoy and over the house of Yisroel because they fell by the sword.
13. Dovid said to the young man who informed him, “Where are you from?” He replied, “I am the son of an Amoleikite convert.”
14. Dovid told him, “How did you not fear thrusting your hand forth to destroy Adonoy’s anointed one?”
15. Dovid called one of the young men and said, “Come here. Execute him.” He struck him and he died.
16. Dovid said to him, “Your blood is on your own head because your own mouth testified against yourself, saying, ‘I killed Adonoy’s anointed one.’”
17. Dovid composed this lamentation on Shaul and his son Yohonoson.
18. He said, “To teach the Bnei Yehudah archery behold it is written in the Seifer HaYoshor.
19. Pillar of Yisroel, on your heights [you have been rendered] a corpse. How the mighty have fallen.
20. Do not tell [this] in Gass, do not announce [this] in the streets of Ashkelon. Lest the daughters of Plishtim rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumsized regale.

21. Mountains in Gilboa, the dew and the rain should not [fall] upon you nor fields [yielding enough for] baking offerings. Because there, the shield of soldiers spit out, the shield of Shaul was not smeared with oil.
22. [Without drawing] from the blood of corpses, [without cutting] from the fat of soldiers, the bow of Yohonasan would not be pulled back. The sword of Shaul was not returned empty.
23. Shaul and Yohonasan, loved and Cherished during their lifetime, During their deaths, they were not separated [from being loved], they were lighter then eagles, they were stronger then lions.
24. Daughters of Yisroel, weep over Shaul who has clothed you in scarlet clothing together with other delights, who has adorned your garments with gold jewelry.
25. How the mighty have fallen during battle. Yohanasan, on your heights, [you were] slain.
26. I anguish over you, my brother Yohansan you were very cherished to me. Your love was more wondrous to me then the love of women.
27. How the mighty have fallen and the weapons of war lost.
1. And after this, Dovid asked of Adonoy saying, “Should I go up to one of the cities of Yehudah?” Adonoy said to him, “Go up.” Dovid said, “Where should I go up to?” And He said, “To Chevron.”
2. Dovid went up there as did his two wives, Achinoam the Yizraelite and Avigayil the [former] wife of Novol from Carmel.
3. Dovid brought up his men that were with him, each man and his household, and they settled in the cities of Chevron.
4. The people of Yehudah came and anointed Dovid there to be the king over Beis Yehudah. They informed Dovid, telling [him] that the people of Yoveish Gilod had buried Shaul.

5. Dovid sent messengers to the people of Yoveish Gilod and he said to them, “You should be blessed before Adonoy for this kindness that you have done for your master, for Shaul, that which you buried him.”
6. “And now, Adonoy should do kindness and truth unto you. I will also do the same unto you for this good deed, that you have done.”
7. “Now, strengthen you hands and become brave because your master Shaul has died, and the House of Yehudah have anointed me to be king over them.”
8. Avner, the son of Ner, Shaul’s military chief of staff took Ish Boshes, the son of Shaul and brought him to Machanoyim.
9. He made him king over Gilod, over Asher, over Yizrael, over Ephraim, over Binyomin and over all Yisroel.
10. Forty year old was Ish Boshes, the son of Shaul when he reigned over Yisroel. He reigned for two years. But the House of Yehuda followed David.
11. And the number of years, that David was king in Chevron, over the house of Yehuda was seven years and six months.
12. Avner, the son of Ner and the servants of Ish Boshes, the son of Shaul left Machanoyim and went to Givon
13. Yoav, the son of Tseruyoh and David’s servants went out and met with them at the pool of Givon. One party sat on one side of the pool and the other party sat on the other side.
14. Avner said to Yoav, “Let the young soldiers get up and playfight before us.” And Yoav said, “Let them get up.”
15. And they got up and crossed over to the other side [of the pool] in even numbers — twelve from [the tribe of] Binyamin, for Ish Boshes, the son of Shaul, and twelve from the servants of Dovid.
16. Each of the men grabbed his opponent’s head and [thrust] his sword in his opponent’s side, and they all fell [dead] together. That place was called the plain of swords which is in Givon.
17. The fighting was intense on that day, Avner and men of Yisroel were beaten by the servants of Dovid.
18. The three sons of Tseruyoh were there Yoav, Avishai and Asoel. Asoel was light on his feet, like one of the deer in a field.
19. Asoel chased after Avner, and did not stray right or left from pursuing Avner.
20. Avner turned around and said, “Are you Asoel?” and he replied, “It is I.”
21. Avner said to him, “Stray to your right or your left, and grab for yourself one of the soldiers, and take for yourself his weapon. Asoel did not want to veer off from [running] after him.

22. Avner continued and said to Asoel, “Veer off from [running] after me. Why should I strike you [dead] to the ground? How will I face your brother?” He refused to veer off and Avner hit him with the back of the spear into the fifth rib. The spear came out from the back of him and he fell there and died in his place. And it was that all [the pursuers] who reached the place where Asoel fell and died, stopped [their pursuit].
24. Yoav and Avishai chased after Avner, and the sun set [as] they had reached Givas Amoh that faces Giach on the way to the desert of Givon.
25. The men of Binyomin regrouped behind Avner and became one unit and they stood atop a mountain.
26. Avner called to Yoav and said, “Will the sword be killing forever? You know it will come to a bitter end. For how long will you not tell the people to turn around and not pursue their brothers.”
27. Yoav said, By the life of Elokim, if you had not spoken [earlier] then already from the morning the people would have gone up [and left] each man [from pursuing] after his brother.
28. Yoav blew the Shofer. All the people stopped and no longer pursued after [the men of] Yisroel. They no longer continued to fight [with them].
29. Avner and his men traveled in the plain all that night. They crossed the Yardein, and traveled through all of the Bisron [region] and they came to Machanoim.
30. Yoav turned away from [chasing] after Avner and he gathered all the people. There was missing from the servants of Dovid, [a total of] nineteen men and Asoel.
31. Dovid’s servants killed [many] from the people of Binyomin and of Avner’s men. Three hundred and sixty men died.
32. They carried Asoel and buried him in the grave of his father that is in Beis Lechem. Yoav and his men traveled all night and dawn [broke] for them [as they came] in [to] Chevron.
1. There was a long war between the house of Shaul and the house of Dovid. Dovid was [continuosly] getting stronger, and the house of Shaul was [continuously] getting weaker.
2. Sons were born to Dovid in Chevron, his first born was Amnon by Achinoam the Yiszraelite.
3. His second [son] was Kilov by Avigayil, the wife of Novol the Carmelite. The third [son] was Avsholom, the son of Maachoh, the daughter of Talmai, the king of Geshur.
4. The fourth [son] was Adoniyoh, the son of Chagis. The fifth [son] was Shephatiyoh, the son of Avital.
5. The sixth [son] was Yisrom by Egloh, the wife of Dovid. These [sons] were born to Dovid in Chevron.
6. While the war was [going on] between the house of Shaul and the house of Dovid, Avner was strengthening the house of Shaul.
7. Shaul had a concubine and her name was Rizpah, the daughter of Ayoh [Ish boshes] said to Avner, “Why have you visited [conjugally] my father’s concubine?”

8. Avner became very angry on account of] the words of Ish Boshes and said, “Am I the chief dog [watcher] for [the kingdom of] Yehuda? From this day on should I [continue to] be kind to the house of Shaul, your father, to his brothers and to his friends? And I have not delivered you into the hand of Dovid. [But] you [still] remember the sin [involving] the woman, [using it] against me today.”
9. “This is what Elokim should do to Avner and so may He do further for as Adonoy swore to Dovid so I shall do for him.”
10. “To remove the monarchy from the house of Shaul and to establish the throne of Dovid over Yisroel and over Yehuda from Don to B’er Sheva”
11. [Ish Boshes] couldn’t answer anything to Avner because of his fear of him.

12. Avner sent messengers to Dovid in his behalf, saying, by He Who [possesses] the land [and] saying [further], “Enact a convenant with me and my hand will be with you to bring all of Yisroel around to you.”

13. He said [in response] “Good, I will enact a convenant with you, but just one thing I ask of you saying, do not see my face unless you first bring Michal, the daughter of Shaul when you come to see my face.”
14. And Dovid sent messengers to Ish Boshes, the son of Shaul saying, “Give me my wife Michal that I betrothed to me with the one hundred foreskins of the Pelishtim
15. And Ish Boshes sent [messengers] and took her from [her] husband from Paltiel, the son of Loyish.
16. Her husband went with her following and crying after her until Bachurim. Avner said to him, “Go return.” and he returned.
17. The word of Avner was [sent] to the elders of Yisroel, saying “Yesterday and also the day before yesterday, you requested that Dovid be king over you.”
18. “And now, do it because Adonoy said about Dovid, ‘through the hand of Dovid My servant I will save My people Yisroel from the hand of the Pelishtim and the hand of all their enemies.’”

19. Avner also spoke to [the people] of Binyomin. Avner also went to speak to Dovid in Chevron all that seemed good in the eyes of Yisroel and in the eyes of all of the house of Binyomin [that Dovid should ascend the throne].
20. Avner came to Dovid in Chevron, and with him were twenty men. Dovid made for Avner and the men with him, a feast.

21. Avner said to Dovid, “I’ll get up and go and I will gather for my master, the king, all of Yisroel. They will enact a convenant with you and you will reign over all that you desire.” Dovid sent Avner [to do this] and he went in peace.

22. And it was that the servants of Dovid and Yoav came back from an attack and brought with them a large booty. Avner was not with Dovid in Chevron because [Dovid] had sent him off and he had gone in peace.
23. Yoav and all of the army with him came and Yoav was told, “Avner, the son of Ner came to the king and [the king] sent him off, and he went in peace.”
24. Yoav came to the king and said, “What did you do? Here Avner came to you, why did you send him off and he went?”
25. “You know Avner, the son of Ner, he came to seduce you and to know about your goings and comings and to know about everything you do.”
26. Yoav went out from [before] Dovid. [He then] sent messengers after Avner and they returned him from Bor HaSiroh. Dovid was unaware [of this].

27. Avner returned to Chevron and Yoav steered him to go within the gate to talk to him, deceptively, [Yoav] hit him there into the fifth rib and [Avner] died on account of the blood of Asoel, [Yoav’s] brother.
28. And afterwards, when Dovid heard [about this] he said, I and my kingdom are innocent, from [before] Adonoy forever, from the blood of Avner, the son of Ner.

29. [The guilt] should fall on the head of Yoav and on his father’s entire house. There should never cease from the house of Yoav, [the afflictions of] a discharging man, a leper, [a lame person] who leans on a cane, [a person] felled by the sword and [a person] lacking bread.
30. Yoav and his brother Avishai killed Avner because he killed their brother Asoel in Givon, in battle.
31. Dovid said to Yoav and to all the people that were with him, “Rent your clothes, tie on sackcloth and eulogize before Avner,” and King Dovid himself followed the coffin.
32. They buried Avner in Chevron, and the king lifted up his voice and wept over Avner’s grave and all the people wept.
33. The king lamented over Avner and said, “Should Avner have died the death of the wicked?
34. Your hands were not bound, your feet were not put into bronze chains. Like those who fell before treacherous men you have fallen.” All the people continued to cry over him.

35. All the people came to offer Dovid [the mourner’s] bread while it was still daytime. Dovid swore saying, “Such should Elokim do to me and even more so if, before sunset, I should taste bread or anything else.”
36. All the people recognized [that Dovid wasn’t involved] and [this] was good in their eyes. Everything the king did was good in the eyes of all the people.
37. All of the people and all Yisroel knew on that day that it was not [an order] from the king to kill Avner, the son of Ner.
38. And the king said to his servants You know that an officer and a great man fell on this day in Yisroel.
39. I am today weak [as a commoner] and only just annointed king and these men, the sons of Tseruyoh are tougher then me. Adonoy will repay the evildoer according to his evil deed.
1. The son of Shaul heard that Avner had died in Chevron. His hands weakened and all of Yisroel trembled.

2. Two men were officers of troops for the son of Shaul, the name of one was Ba’anoh and the name of the second was Raichov. [They were] the sons of Rimon the Be’erosite from the people of Binyomin because Be’eros was also considered part of Binyomin.
3. The Be’erosites fled to Gitoim and they lived there until this day.

4. Yahonoson, the son of Shaul had a son with broken feet. He was five years old when the news came regarding [the deaths of] Yahonoson and Shaul from Yiszrael. His nurse picked him up and fled. [However,] in her haste to flee he fell and was rendered lame, and his name was Mephiboshes
5. The sons of Rimon the Be’erosite went, Raichov and Ba’anoh, and they came during the heat of the day into the house of Ish Boshes, He was sleeping [during] his afternoon nap.
6. They came into the interior of the house [together with] wheat buyers, and they hit him in the fifth rib. [Then] Raichov and his brother Ba’anoh escaped.
7. They came into the house and he was sleeping on his bed in his bedroom. They hit him and killed him, and they removed his head. They took his head and they traveled westwardly all night.

8. They brought the head of Ish Boshes to Dovid in Chevron and they said to the king, “Here is the head of Ish Boshes, the son of Shaul, your enemy, that sought to kill you. Adonoy has delivered to my master, the king, vengeance on this day from Shaul and his offspring.”
9. Dovid responded to Raichov and his brother Ba’ano the sons of Rimon the Be’erosite and said to them, “By the living Adonoy that saved me from all anguish.

10. When the person told me, saying, ‘Behold, Shaul has died,’ he thought he was announcing good tidings [but] I seized him and killed him in Ziklog. He thought I would reward him for his good tidings.

11. Even [more so I am displeased] that these wicked men killed a righteous man in his house on his bed. And now, I will seek [vengeance for] his blood from your hands and I will eradicate you from the land.

12. Dovid gave orders to the young soldiers and they killed them. They cut off their hands and their feet and they hung them by the pool in Chevron. They took the head of Ish Boshes and they buried it by Avner’s burial place in Chevron.
1. All the tribes of Yisroel came to Chevron, to Dovid and they said, “We are your bone and your flesh.”

2. Both yesterday and the day before yesterday while Shaul was king over us you were the one who took out and brought back Yisroel, and Adonoy said to you, ‘You will lead my people Yisroel and you will be a prince over Yisroel.’” All the elders of Yisroel came to Chevron to the king and King Dovid enacted a pact with them in Chevron before Adonoy and they anointed Dovid to be king over Yisroel.
4. Dovid was a man of thirty years when he [first] reigned. He was king for forty years.
5. In Chevron, he reigned over Yehudah for seven years and six months and in Yerushaloyim he reigned for thirty-three years over all of Yisroel and Yehuda.

6. The king and his men went to Yerusholoyim to the Yevusim who dwelled in that land. He said to Dovid, You shall not come lest you [are able to] remove [the idols depicting] the blind and the lame which are saying, ‘Dovid will not come here.’
7. Dovid conquored the fortress of Tzion This is [now] the city of Dovid.

8. Dovid said on that day, “Whoever kills the Yevusi and touches [and destroys] the tower’s spire and [the idols of] the lame and the blind, which were abhored by Dovid, upon which they are saying, ‘[While] the blind one and the lame one [are here], [Dovid] will not come into the house.’”
9. Dovid settled in the fortress, and he called it the city of Dovid. Dovid built around [the fortress], from it’s low wall and inwards.
10. Dovid became continuously greater, and Adonoy, the God of Legions was with him.
11. Chirom, the king of Tzor sent messengers to Dovid [bringing with them] cedarwood and carpenters and stone cutters [who could build] a wall. They built a house for Dovid.
12. Dovid understood that Adonoy had established him king over Yisroel and that his kingdom had been elevated for the sake of His people Yisroel.
13. Dovid took more concubines and wives from Yerusholoyim after he arrived from Chevron. More sons and daughters were born to Dovid.
14. These are the names of the [children] born to him in Yerusholoyim, Shaua, Shovov, Noson and Shlomo.
15. Yivchor, Elishua, Nepheg and Yophia.
16. Elishoma, Elyodo and Elipholet.
17. The Pelishtim heard that they had anointed Dovid to be king over Yisroel. All the Pelishtim went up seeking [to fight] Dovid. Dovid heard [about this] and descended to the tortress.
18. The Pelishtim came and fanned out acros the valley of Rephaim.

19. Dovid asked of Adonoy, saying, “Should I go up [to fight] the Pelishtim? Will they be delivered into my hands?” Adonoy said to Dovid, “Go up, because I will deliver the Pelishtim into your hands.”

20. Dovid came into the plain of Perotzim. Dovid smote them there and declared, “Adonoy has shatterred my enemies before me like water bursting over [walls]” Because of this, he called the name of that place the plain of Perotzim
21. [The Pelishtim] abandoned their idols there and Dovid and his men burnt them.
22. The Pelishtim continued to go up and fan out across the valley of Repahim.
23. Dovid asked Adonoy [what to do] and He answered, “Do not go up, circle around to their rear and come at them from opposite the trees.”
24. “When you hear the sound of stepping on the tops of the trees then shout out [war whoops] because then Adonoy has gone out before you to smite the Plishtim camp.
25. Dovid did as Adonoy commanded him and he smote the Plishtim from Gevah until you come to Gozer.
1. Dovid again gathered all the chosen men of Yisroel, thirty thousand.

2. Dovid arose and went with all the people that were with him from Baalei Yehuda, to bring up from there the Ark of Elokim, whose name is called by the name of Adonoy of Hosts who dwells upon the Cherubim.
3. They had the Ark of Elokim ride on a new wagon. They carried it from the house of Avinodov that is in Givoh. Uzoh and Achyo, the sons of Avinodov were driving the new wagon.
4. They carried it from the house of Avinodov that was in Givoh accompanying the Ark of Elokim, and Achyo went before the Ark.
5. Dovid and all the house of Yisroel were rejoicing before [the Ark of] Adonoy with all [instruments made of] cypress wood [such as] harps, lyres, drums, coronets and cymbals.
6. They came to the grainery of Nochon and Uzoh stretched [his hand] towards the Ark of Elokim and held it because the ox had [made] it slip.
7. Adonoy became angry with Uzoh and Elokim struck him there because of his mistake. He died there by the Ark of Elokim.
8. Dovid was angered [with himself] concerning the breach of Uzoh and he called that place Peretz Uzoh until this day.
9. Dovid feared Adonoy on that day, He said, “How shall the Ark of Adonoy come to me.”
10. Dovid did not want to bring the Ark of Adonoy towards him, to the city of Dovid. Dovid carried it aside [to] the house of Oveid Edom the Gittite.
11. The Ark of Adonoy dwelled in the house of Oveid Edom the Gittite for three months, and Adonoy blessed Oveid Edom and his entire household.

12. It was told to King Dovid, saying, “Adonoy has blessed Oveid Edom and all that he has on account of the Ark of Elokim.” Dovid went and brought up the Ark of Elokim from the house of Oveid Edom [to] the city of Dovid, with rejoicing.
13. When the carriers of the Ark of Adonoy stepped six paces, he sacrificed oxen and fattened oxen.
14. Dovid danced with all [his] strength before [the Ark of] Adonoy. Dovid was girded with a linen robe.
15. Dovid and all of the house of Yisroel brought up the Ark of Adonoy with shouting and with the sound of the Shofar.

16. As the Ark of Adonoy came [to] the city of Dovid Michal, the daughter of Shaul was looking through the window. She saw king Dovid dancing and leaping before [the Ark of] Adonoy, and he was disgraced in her heart.
17. They brought the Ark of Adonoy and they set it in its place in the tent that Dovid had spread out for it. Dovid brought up burnt offerings before Adonoy and also peace offerings.
18. Dovid finished bringing up the burnt offering and the peace offerings and he blessed the people with the Name of Adonoy of Hosts.

19. He distributed to all the people, to the whole multitude of Yisroel whether man or woman, for each person one loaf of bread, a portion of meat and a jug [of wine]. The people left, each person to his house.

20. Dovid returned to bless his household. Michal, the daughter of Shaul went out to greet Dovid and she said, “How glorious is this day! The king of Yisroel revealed [himself] today [before] the eyes of the handmaidens of his servants as one of the riff-raff reveals [himself].”
21. Dovid said to Michal, “Before Adonoy, Who has chosen me [over] your father and all his household, charging me to be ruler over the people of Adonoy, over Yisroel, I rejoiced before Adonoy.
22. [Had] I made light of myself even more then this, and lowered myself in my [own] eyes and with the handmaidens that you mentioned, I woud be more honoured among them.”
23. Michal, the daughter of Shaul had no child until the day of her death.
1. When the king dwelled in his house and Adonoy granted him rest from all his enemies around [him].
2. The king said to the prophet Noson, “See now, I dwell in a house of cedar wood and the Ark of Elokim dwells within a curtain.”
3. Noson said to the king, “All that is in your heart, go do because Adonoy is with you.”
4. And it was on that night, the word of Adonoy [came] to Noson saying.
5. Go and say to my servant Dovid, “Thus said Adonoy, ‘Is it you that will build for Me a house for My dwelling?’
6. ‘For I have not dwelled in a house from the day I brought up the Bnei Yisroel from Egypt until this day, but have travelled within a tent and the Mishkan.’

7. ‘In all [the places] that I have traveled amongst the Bnei Yisroel, have I said a word to one of the rulers of Yisroel that I have commanded to lead my people Yisroel saying, ‘Why haven’t you built me a house of cedarwood?”

8. ‘And now, this is what you should say to my servant Dovid, this is what Adonoy of Hosts says, ‘I have taken you from the corral, from [following] behind the sheep to be a prince over My people Yisroel.”
9. ‘I will be with you wherever you go’ ‘I will destroy all your enemies from before you.’ I will make for you a great name like the name of great people that are in the land.

10. ‘I will make a place for My people Yisroel and I will root [the people in their land] and [the people] will dwell [in their land] and they will not be removed [from the land], and the wicked will no longer afflict [the people] as before.’
11. ‘And from the day that I commanded Judges over My people Yisroel.’ ‘I will give you respite from all your enemies.’ Adonoy is telling you that He will establish a monarchy for you.
12. ‘When your days are filled and you are [laid] to rest with your fathers, I will establish your offspring after you that will emerge from your bowels; and I will establish his monarchy.’
13. ‘He will build a Temple for My Name and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.’
14. ‘I will be a Father to him and he will be a son to Me. Should he commit iniquity I will rebuke him with the rod of men and with the afflictions of people.’
15. ‘My kindness will not depart from him as I removed it from Shaul Whom I have removed from before you’
16. ‘Your House and monarchy will be established forever before you,’ Your throne will be established forever.’
17. All these things and this entire vision, Noson told it to Dovid.
18. King Dovid came and sat before the Ark of Adonoy and said, “Who am I, my Master Elokim and who is my household that You have brought me until this point.

19. This was yet small in your eyes, my Master Elokim, that You have spoken also about the house of your servant [and generations] in the distant future. Is this announcement [fitting] for [mere] man, my Master Elokim.
20. What more can Dovid say to You? You know Your servant, my Master Elokim.
21. Because of Your word and due to [the will of] Your Heart, You have made [given me] all this greatness of which You have informed Your servant.
22. Through this [I understand] that You are great my Master Elokim, because there is no other like You and there is no other god but You according to all that we heard with out ears.

23. Who is like Your people, like Yisroel a unique nation in the world, for whom leaders went [telling Yisroel, “Our mission is to redeem for Him, a people to put forth His Name, and to make great [things happen] for you.” [You have done] awesome things for your land, from before Your people that You have redeemed from Egypt for Yourself, [You have driven out] nations and their gods.
24. You prepared for Yourself your people Yisroel [to be] a people for you until eternity and You Adonoy have been for them, Elokim.
25. And now Adonoy Elokim, the thing that You have spoken concerning You servant and concerning his household establish it forever and do as You said.
26. And Your Name will be great forever [with people] saying, “Adonoy of Hosts, Elokim [rules] over Yisroel” and may the house of Dovid, Your servant be established before You.
27. Because You Adonoy of Hosts, the God of Yisroel revealed to the ear of Your servant saying, “I will build you a House and thus your servant set his heart to pray this prayer to You.
28. And now Adonoy Elokim, You are the Elokim and Your words will be true, and You have spoken, to Your servant, [about] this good [thing to come].

29. And now, may it please You [to] bless the House of Your servant to be forever [servants] before You, for You have spoken, my Master Elokim, and from Your blessings, may the House of Your servant be blessed forever.
1. Afterwords Dovid struck the Pelishtim and humbled them. Dovid took Meseg Hoamoh from the hand of the Pelishtim.

2. He struck Moav and he measured them with a rope. He had them lie down on the ground, those measured with two ropes were killed and those with the fullness of one rope were allowed to live. Moav became Dovid’s slaves, bearers of a [yearly] present [for Dovid].
3. Dovid struck Haddadezer, the son of Rechov the king of Tsovoh, as he went to enlarge his border at the P’ras river.
4. Dovid captured from him one thousand and seven hundred cavalrymen and twenty thousand men on foot. Dovid destroyed all the chariot [horses], [with] one hundred chariot [horses] remaining.
5. Aram Damesek came to help Haddadezer, the king of Tsovoh. Dovid struck among the Aram twenty-two thousand men.
6. Dovid placed officers in Aram Damesek and [the people of] Aram were slaves to Dovid bearers of [an annual] present. Adonoy protected Dovid wherever he went.
7. Dovid took the golden quivers that had belonged to the servants of Heddadezcr and brought them to Yerushalayim.
8. From Betach and from Bairosy, cities of Haddadezer, King Dovid took a large amount of bronze.
9. Toiy the king of Chamos heard that Dovid struck [down] the entire army of Haddadezer.

10. Toiy sent his son Yorom to king Dovid to ask of his peace and to bless him because he had fought against Haddadezer and had struck him [down], for Toiy was enemies with Haddadezer. In his [Yoram’s] hand were silver utensils, gold utensils and bronze utensils.

11. Those [utensils] also king Dovid sanctified for [the service of] Adonoy in addition to the silver and gold that he had sanctified [from what was captured] from all the nations that he had conquered.
12. From Arom, from Moav, from the children of Amon from the Pleshtim and from Amoleik, and from the booty [captured from] Haddadezer, the son of Rechov, the king of Tsovoh.
13. Dovid made a name [for himself] during his return from striking Arom in Gay Melach [and killing] eighteen thousand men.
14. He placed officers in Edom. In all of Edom, he placed officers, and all of Edom were slaves to Dovid. Adonoy protected Dovid wherever he went.
15. Dovid ruled over all of Yisroel and Dovid rendered judgment and righteousness unto all of his people.
16. Yoav, the son of Tsruyoh was [commander] over the army and Yehoshophot, the son of Achilud was the announcer [of halachic cases].
17. Tsodok, the son of Achituv and Achimelech, the son of Evyosor were [leaders of] the Kohanim and Seroyoh was the scribe
18. Venoyohu, the son of Yehoyodoh [was in charge of] the archers and the sling shooters. The sons of Dovid were [prominent] leaders.
1. Dovid said, “Is there anyone left of the House of Shaul [so that] I may render kindness unto him for Yohonoson’s sake?”
2. The House of Shaul had a slave, his name was Tsivoh, and they called him to [meet] Dovid. The king said to him, “Are you Tsivoh?” He said, “I am your servant.”

3. The king said, “Is there any man left of the House of Shaul [so that] I may render unto him the kindness of Elokim?” Tzivoh said to the king, “There is still a son left to Yohonoson [crippled with] broken legs.”
4. The king said to him, “Where is he?” Tsivoh said to the king, “He is in the house of Mochir, the son of Amiel in Lo Dvor”
5. King Dovid sent [for him] and took him from the house of Mochir, the son of Amiel from Lo Dvor.
6. Mephivoshes, the son of Yohonoson, the son of Shaul came to Dovid. He fell on his face and prostrated himself. Dovid said, Mephivoshes? And he said, “Here is your servant.”

7. Dovid said to him, “Do not fear because I will render kindness unto you for the sake of your father Yohonoson. I will return to you the entire field [estate] of your father Shaul and you will eat bread at my table perpetually.”
8. He [Mephivoshes] prostrated himself and said, “What [am I], your servant that you turned toward a dead dog like myself?”
9. The king called Tzivoh Shaul’s servant and said to him, “All that which belonged to Shaul and to his House, I have given to the son of your master.

10. You will work the land for him, you, your children and your servants. You will bring in [the produce] and it will be food for the son of your master and he will eat it. And Mephivoshes, the son of your master. will always eat bread at my table.” Tsivoh had fifteen sons and twenty slaves.
11. Tsivoh said to the king, “All that my master, the king commands his servant so will your servant do.” “Mephivoshes will eat at my table like one of the sons of the king.”
12. Mephivoshes had a small son, his name was Michoh, all those who dwelled in the house of Tsivoh were slaves to Mephivoshes
13. Mephivoshes dwelled in Yerusholayim because he always ate at the King’s table and he was lame [on] both his legs.
1. And it was, afterwords [that] the king of the people of Amon died and Chonun, his son reigned in his stead.

2. Dovid said, “I will act with kindness towards Chonun, the son of Nochosh as his father acted with kindness towards me.” Dovid sent to console him by the hand of his servants about his father. The servants of Dovid came to the land of the people of Amon.

3. The officers of the people of Amon said to Chonun, their master, “Do you think Dovid honors your father because he has sent [representatives] to console you? It is to investigate the city and to spy on it and to overthrow it [that] Dovid has sent his servants to you.”
4. Chonun took Dovid’s servants and shaved off half their beards and tore their clothes halfway, [down] to their buttocks and sent them [away].
5. It was told to Dovid and he sent to meet them because the men were very ashamed. The king said, “stay in Yeraicho until your beards grow [back] and [then] return.”

6. The people of Amon saw that they were disgusting to Dovid. The people of Amon sent and hired Aram, of the house of Rechov and Aram Tsovoh, twenty thousand foot soldiers and king Machoh, a thousand men and Ish Tov, twelve thousand men.
7. Dovid heard [this] and sent Yoav and the whole army of mighty men.
8. The people of Amon went out and arranged war at the opening of the gate. And Aram Tsovoh, Rechov, Ish Tov and Machoh were by themselves [as a second flank] in the field.
9. Yoav saw that the fronts of the battle were [against] him from the front and from the rear. He chose from all the young men of Yisroel and set up to meet the men of Arom.
10. The rest of the people he gave to his brother Avshai and set up to meet the people of Amon.
11. [Yoav] said, “If Arom overpowers me you [come] to save me and if the people of Amon overpower you I will go to save you.
12. You be strong and we should be strong for the sake of our people and for the cities of our God and Adonoy will do what’s good in His Eyes.”
13. Yoav and the people with him approached to [engage in] battle with the men of Arom and they fled from before him.

14. The people of Amon saw that the men of Arom had fled and they fled from before Avishai and went [back into] the city. Yoav returned from [fighting] against the people of Amon and he came to Yerusholoyim.
15. The men of Arom saw that they were stricken before Yisroel and they gathered together.
16. Hadadezer sent and brought out the men of Arom that were across the river. They came to Chailom and Shovach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army was in front of them.
17. It was told to Dovid and he gathered all of Yisroel. He crossed over the Yardein and came to Chailomoh. The men of Arom set up to meet Dovid and fought with him.
18. The men of Arom fled from before Yisroel. Dovid killed from Arom the men of seven hundred chariots and forty thousand horseman. He struck Shovach, the commander of their army and he died there.
19. All the kings, the servants of Hadadezer saw that they were stricken before Yisroel. They made peace with Yisroel and served them. The men of Arom were afraid to help the people of Amon any more.

1. And it was at the turn of the year at the time [of year] when kings go forth. Dovid sent Yoav, and his servants with him and all of Yisroel. They destroyed the people of Amon and they beseiged Rabboh [while] Dovid dwelled in Yerushalayim.
2. And it was at evening time, and Dovid got up from his bed and was walking on the palace roof. He saw a woman bathing from [his vantage point] on the rooftop and the woman was very beautiful.
3. Dovid sent and inquired about the woman and he said, “Is this not Bas Shevah, the daughter of Eliom the wife of Urioh, the Hitite.”
4. Dovid sent messengers and took her. She came to him and he laid with her, for she had purified herself from her uncleanliness and she returned to her house.
5. And the woman conceived and sent and told Dovid and said, “I have conceived.”
6. Dovid sent to Yoav, “Send me Urioh, the Hitite.” Yoav sent Urioh to Dovid.
7. Urioh came to him Dovid asked about Yoav’s welfare, the welfare of the people and the welfare of the [soldiers at] war.
8. Dovid said to Urioh, “Go down to your house and wash your legs.” Urioh left the king’s palace the king’s meal followed him.
9. Urioh slept at the door of the king’s palace with all his master’s servants and he did not go down to his house.
10. They told to Dovid saying, “Urioh did not go down to his house.” Dovid said to Urioh, “You are coming [back] from travelling, why did you not go down to your house.”

11. Urioh said to Dovid, “The Ark, Yisroel and Yehudah are living in temporary dwellings, and my master Yoav [along with] my master’s servants are camping out in the field, and I am going to go to my house to eat and to drink and to sleep with my wife? [Upon] your life and the life of your soul if I should do such a thing.”
12. Dovid said to Urioh, “Stay here today and tommorrow I shall send you [back].” Urioh stayed in Yerosholoyim on that day and [into] the next.
13. Dovid summoned him and ate before him and drank and inebriated him. At evening he went out to sleep in his bed together with the servants of his master. He did not go down to his house.
14. And it was in the morning Dovid wrote a letter to Yoav and sent it in the hand of Urioh.
15. He wrote in the letter saying, “Put Urioh up against the front of the strong [intense] battle and retreat behind him and he will be struck and killed.”
16. During Yoav’s watching of the city, he put Urioh into a place where he knew mighty soldiers were.
17. The men of the city went out and fought with Yoav. And there fell some of the people, of Dovid’s servants, and Urioh the Chitite also died [there].
18. Yoav sent [a message], and told Dovid [about] all the battle’s events.
19. He commanded the messenger, saying, “When you finish relating all the events of the war to the king.
20. Should the king [then] get angry and say to you, ‘Why did you go [so] close to the city to fight, you knew they would throw [projectiles on you] from [the edge of] the wall?

21. Who struck Avimelech, the son of Yerubeshes? A woman threw [down] on him a millstone from [the edge of] the wall and he died in Tavaitz. Why did you go [so] close to the wall [of the city]?’ You should say [in reply] ‘Your servant Urioh the Chitite also died.’ ”
22. The messenger went and came and told Dovid everything that Yoav sent him [to relate].
23. The messenger said to Dovid, “When the [enemy] men overpowered us, they came out to [engage us in] the field. We [then] were upon them until the entrance of the gate.
24. The throwers threw down [objects] on your servants from atop the wall. Some of the king’s servants were killed and your servant Urioh, the Chitite also died.”

25. Dovid said to the messenger, “Say this to Yoav, ‘This thing should not be evil in your eyes for the sword consumes one as well as others. Intensity your war [against] the city and destroy it’ and encourage him [Yoav].”
26. Urioh’s wife heard that her husband Urioh had died and she lamented her husband.
27. When the mourning period passed, Dovid sent [for her] and gathered her into his house, and she became a wife to him, and she gave birth to a son by him What Dovid did was bad in the eyes of God.
1. Adonoy sent Noson to Dovid. He came to him and said to him, “Two men were in the [same] one city, one rich and one poor.
2. The rich one possesed very many flocks and cattle.

3. The poor one had nothing but one little lamb that he had bought and nourished it and it grew up with him and his sons together. It ate from his bread and drank from his cup and slept in his bosom and was like a daughter to him.

4. A traveler came to the rich man, [who] had pity and took from his flocks and his cattle to make [a meal] for the guest that had come to him. He took the poor man’s lamb and made it [a meal] for the man that had come to him.
5. Dovid became very angry with the man and he said to Noson, “[By] the life of God, the man who does this is worthy of death.
6. And for the lamb he should pay fourfold because he did this thing and because he had no pity.”
7. Noson said to Dovid, “You are that man. Thus said God, the God of Yisroel, ‘I have anointed you king over Yisroel and I have saved you from the hand of Shaul.
8. I have given you your master’s house and your master’s woman in your bosom. I have given you the house of Yisroel and Yehudah if this is [too] little I will add on for you like this and like this.

9. Why did you desecrate the word of God to do [what’s] bad in his eyes? You struck [down] Urioh the Chitite with the sword and his wife you took as a wife for yourself. Him, you killed with the sword of the people of Amon.
10. And now the sword will never cease from your house on account of you having degraded Me, and you have taken the wife of Urioh, the Chitite to be for you as a wife.

11. Thus said God, I will cause evil to you from your [own] house, I will take your wives [in front of] your eyes and I will give [them] to your friend. He will lay with your wives in the eyes [sight] of this sun.
12. Because you have done [your misdeed] clandestinely I will do this thing in front of all Yisroel and in front of the sun.’ ”
13. Dovid said to Noson, “I have sinned [against] Adonoy.” Noson said to Dovid, “Adonoy has also removed your sin, you shall not die.
14. Because [You have angered] the enemies of Adonoy [through] this affair, the son born to you will also die:
15. Noson went [back] to his house. and Adonoy struck the boy that the wife of Urioh bore to Dovid and he became sick.
16. Dovid supplicated Elokim on behalf of the boy. Dovid fasted and came to repose and lied on the ground.
17. The elders of his house went to him to get him up from the ground. He did not want [to] and he did not eat bread with them.

18. On the seventh day, the boy died. Dovid’s servants were afraid to tell him that the boy had died because they [reasoned and] said, “When the boy was alive, we spoke to him [Dovid] and he did not heed our voice. How are we going to say to him, ‘The boy died’? He will do [something] bad [to himself].”
19. Dovid saw that his servants were whispering, Dovid understood that the boy had died. Dovid said to his servants, “Did the boy die?” They said [in reply], “He died.”

20. Dovid got up from the ground, he bathed and anointed [himself] and changed his clothes. He went to the House of Adonoy and bowed down. He came [back] to his house and asked [for food]. They put bread [before him] and he ate.
21. His servants said to him, “What is this thing that you have done? For a live boy you fasted and cried, and when the boy died you got up and ate bread?”
22. He said [in reply], “While the boy was [still] alive I fasted and cried because I [reasoned] and said, ‘Who knows? God [may] be gracious to me and [have] the boy live.’
23. And now [that the boy is] dead why should I fast? Can I any longer [cause] him to return? I am going to him, he is not returning to me.
24. Dovid consoled his wife Bas Sheva. He came to her and lay with her. She gave birth to a son, She called him the name Shlomo, and God loved him [Shlomo].
25. He [God] sent by the hand of Noson the prophet [a message], and he [Dovid] called his name Yedidyoh because of Adonoy.
26. Yoav battled against [the city] Rabbas of the people of Ammon and captured the royal city.
27. Yoav sent messengers to Dovid and said, “I have battled [against] Rabboh. I have also captured the city of water.
28. And now, gather the rest of the people and encamp [against] the city and capture it. Lest I capture the city and my name will be called upon it.
29. Dovid gathered all the people and went to Rabboh. He waged war against it and captured it.
30. He took the crown of Malkom from its head, its weight was a golden kikor and [in it] was a precious stone. It was [hung over] Dovid’s head. He took out much booty [from] the city.

31. He took out the people that were in it. He put them in saw-like utensils, iron threshing utensils and iron axes. He had them pass [through] the streets. He did this to all the cities of the people of Ammon. Dovid and all the people returned to Yerushaloyim.
1. And it was after this, that Avsholom, the son of Dovid had a pretty sister, whose name was Tomor and Amnon, the son of Dovid loved her.
2. Amnon was anguished to [the point of] sickness because of [his love for] his sister Tomor because she was a virgin. It was hidden from the eyes of Amnon [how] to do anything to her.
3. Amnon had a friend, whose name was Yonodov, the son of Shimoh the brother of Dovid. Yonodov was a very smart men.
4. He said to him, Why are you like this, so weak every morning, son of the king? Tell me.” Amnon said to him, “I love Tomor, the sister of my brother Avsholom.”

5. Yehonodov said to him, “Lie on your bed and [pretend to] be sick. Your father will come to see you, and [then] tell him, ‘Please have my sister Tomor come and feed me a meal. She should make the meal [before] my eyes in order that I should see [it] and I will eat from her hand.’ ”

6. Amnon lied down and [pretended] he was sick. The king came to see him. and Amnon said to the king, “Please have my sister Tomor come and make two dumplings [before] my eyes and I will eat from her hand.”
7. Dovid sent for Tomor in the house saying, “Go to the house of your brother Amnon and make him a meal.
8. Tomor went to the house of her brother Amnon and he was lying down. She took dough and kneaded it, she made a paste [before] his eyes and she cooked the dumplings.
9. She took the pan and poured them out before him, but he refused to eat. Amnon said, “All men should leave me.” And all the men left him.
10. Amnon said to Tomor, “Bring me the food into the room and I will eat from your hand.” Tomor took the dumplings that she made and brought them into the room to her brother Amnon.
11. She brought them near to him to eat, and he grabbed her and said to her, “Come lie with me my sister.”
12. She said to him, “No, my brother, do not rape me because this is not done in Yisroel. Do not commit this disgrace.
13. And me, where will I take my shame? You will be as one of the lowlives in Yisroel. Now, please speak to the king because he will not keep me from you.
14. He did not want to listen to her voice and he overpowered her, raped her and laid with her.
15. Amnon hated her with very great hatred for greater was the hatred that he hated her then the love with which he had loved her, and Amnon told her, “Get up, go.”
16. She said to him, “Do not do this thing, this is a greater evil then the other [first] one that you have done to me to send me away.” He did not want to listen to her.
17. He called his boy that was attending to him and he said, “Please send this [women] from before me outside and close the door after her.”
18. And upon her was her multicolored robe because the virgin daughters of the king wore [such] robes. His servant brought her outside and closed the door after her.
19. Tomor put dirt on her head and tore the multicolored robe that was on her. She put her hand on her head and she went forth crying [as she went].

20. Her brother said to her, “Was your brother Haiminon [Amnon] with you? And now [that its done] my sister keep quiet, he is your brother. Do not put your heart to this matter.” Tomor returned desolate to the house of her brother Avsholom.
21. King Dovid heard all these things and became very angry.
22. Avsholom did not speak with Amnon neither bad or good because Avsholom hated Amnon because he had raped his sister, Tomor.
23. Two years [later], they were shearing for Avsholom in Baal Chatsor which is near Ephraim. Avsholom invited all the king’s sons.
24. Avsholom came to the king and said, “They are shearing for your servant, may the king and his servants go with your servant.”
25. The king said to Avsholom, “No, my son. Let us not all go and let us not all weigh [too] heavy upon you,” He [Avsholom] beseeched him [Dovid], [but] he did not want to and blessed him.
26. Avsholom said, “Will not my brother Amnon come with us?” The king said to him, “Why should he go with you?”
27. Avsholom beseeched him [Dovid] and he sent Amnon with him [with] all the king’s sons.

28. Avsholom commanded his young men saying, “Look out for [when] Amnon’s heart is happy from wine and I tell you ‘Strike Amnon’ and kill him, do not fear; because I commanded you [to do so]. Be strong and be valiant.”
29. Avsholom’s young men did to Amnon as Avsholom commanded. All the king’s sons rose, and each man mounted his mule and they fled.
30. As they were on the way the news came to Dovid saying, “Avsholom struck [down] all the king’s children and not one is left.”
31. The king rose, he rent his clothes and he laid down on the ground. All his servants stood by with torn clothes.

32. Yonodov replied, he was the son of Shimoh [who was] Dovid’s brother and said, “My master, do not say that all the young men, the sons of the king were killed because only Amnon died. Because this has been Avsholom’s order from the day he [Amnon] raped his sister, Tomor.
33. And now, Let not my master, the king take this thing to his heart saying, ‘All the king’s sons died,’ for only Amnon died.”
34. Avsholom fled. The lookout boy lifted his eyes and saw that there was a great multitude following after him on the highway by the side of the mountain.
35. Yonodov said to the king, “The king’s sons have come [back], as the words of your servant [described] so it was.
36. And as he finished speaking, the king’s sons came and lifted up their voices and wept. So too, the king and all his servants wept greatly.
37. Avsholom fled and went to Talmy, the son of Amihud, the king of Geshur He [Dovid] mourned his son all the days.
38. Avsholom fled and went to Geshur and was there for three years.
39. King Dovid desired to go out to Avsholom because he was consoled concerning the death of Amnon.
1. Yoav, the son of Tsruyoh knew that the king’s heart was [favorable] to Avsholom.

2. Yoav sent to Tekoah and took a wise woman from there. He said to her, “Please pretend to be a mourner and wear mourner’s clothes and do not annoint yourself with oil. Be as woman that for many days had mourned for the dead.
3. [Then] you should come [before] the king and speak to him the following words. Yoav put the words in her mouth.
4. The Tekois woman greeted the king and fell to the ground on her face and said, “Help [me] O king.”
5. The king said to her, “What is with you?” She said [in reply], “In truth, I am a widowed woman, my husband is dead.
6. Your handmaid had two sons. Both were fighting [each other] in the field; and no one was able to save [separate] them. One [of them] struck the other one and killed him.

7. Then the entire family rose up against your handmaid and said, ‘Give us the one who killed his brother and we will kill him for the soul of his brother whom he murdered, we shall also destroy the heir.’ They will extinguish my coal that is left, preventing the perpetuation of my husband’s name nor anything remaining [of him] on the face of the earth.”
8. The king said to the woman, “Go [back] to your house and I will command [someone] concerning you.”
9. The Tekois woman said to the king, “My master, the king, the sin is upon me and on my father’s house and the king and his throne are innocent.”
10. The king said [in reply], “The one who is speaking to you [threatingly], bring him to me and he will not touch you any more.

11. She said, “Please remember Adonoy, your God, and not give more [time] for the avenger to destroy. Do not let them destroy my son.” He said [in reply], “As Adonoy lives; if any hair from your son shall fall to the ground.”
12. The woman said, “Please let your handmaiden say something to my master, the king.” He [Dovid] said, “Talk.”
13. The woman said, “Why did you think this about the people of God? that which the king said, he himself is guilty of in order that the king not bring back his exiled [son].

14. We are [all] going to die, like water spilled on the ground that will not be regathered, God will not countenance anyone. but now let him devise means so that the exiled exiled one remain not an outcast.

15. And therefore now I came to speak to my master, the king these words [as a parable] because the people frightened me. Your handmaiden said, ‘I will speak to the king, perhaps the king will take action [in accordance with] his handmaiden’s words.
16. When the king hears [and agrees] to save his handmaiden from the [avenger] man’s hand who woukd destroy me and my son together from the inheritance [given by] God.

17. Your handmaiden says let the words of my master, the king provide relief because just as an angel of God so too is my master the king [able] to discern good and bad. Adonoy your God should be with you.”
18. The king replied and said to the woman, “Please do not conceal from me the matter that I am going to ask you.” The woman said, “My master the king, please speak.”

19. The king said, “Is Yoav’s hand with you in all of this?” The woman replied and said, “By your life, my master, the king, it is impossible to go right or left from all that my master, the king has said because [indeed] your servant, Yoav, he is the one who commanded me and he put in your handmaiden’s mouth all these words.

20. In order to skirt around the [direct] face of the matter has your servant, Yoav done this thing. [But] my master is wise like the wisdom possessed by an angel of God to know everything [going on] in the land.”
21. The king said to Yoav, “Behold you have done this [so] go and bring back the boy, Avsholom.”

22. Yoav fell on his face to the ground and prostrated himself and blessed the king. Yoav said, “Today your servant knows that I have found favor in your eyes my master, the king [as] the king has fulfilled the word of your servant.”
23. Yoav got up went to Goshur and brought Avsholom back to Yerusholayim.
24. The king said, “He should make his way around to his house and he should not see my face.” Avsholom made his way around to his house and he did not see the king’s face.
25. There was no man as beautiful as Avsholom in all of Yisroel to be so much praised from the heel of his foot to the crown of his head there was no blemish.

26. When he shaved his head, it was at the end of each year that he shaved because [the hair] weighed heavily upon him and [so] he shaved it off. The hair of his head weighed two hundred shekalim using the king’s stone [weight].
27. To Avsholom was born three sons and one daughter, Her name was Tomor, she was a beautiful woman.
28. Avsholom lived in Yerusholoyim for two years and did not see the king’s face.
29. Avsholom sent [a message] to Yoav asking [Yoav] to go to the king, He [Yoav] refused to come to him [Avsholom]. He sent another [message] a second time and he [Yoav] refused to come.
30. He [Avsholom] said to his servants, “Look Yoav’s plantation is near mine, and he has barley there. Go and set it on fire, and Avsholom’s servants set the plantation on fire.
31. Yoav got up and went to Avsholom in [his] house. He said to him, why did your servants set my plantation on fire?”

32. Avsholom said to Yoav, “Behold I sent [a message] to you saying, ‘Come here and I will send you to king saying, ‘Why have you brought me from Geshur? It would be better for me if I were still there. And now, let me see the king’s face and if I have a sin [then] kill me.’ ”
33. Yoav came to the king and told him [the message]. He [Dovid] summoned Avsholom. He came to the king he prostrated himself on his face to the ground before the king, and the king kissed Avsholom.
1. It was after this that Avsholom made [for himself] a chariot [with] horses and [an entourage of] fifty men ran before him.

2. Avsholom would rise early, and stand next to the gateway and any man who had a complaint and was coming to the king for judgment, Avsholom would call to him saying, “From what city are you?” He [the complainant] would say “Your servant is from one of the tribes of Yisroel.”
3. Avsholom would say to him, “Look your words are good and correct, [but] Your case will not be heard by the king.
4. Avsholom said, “Who will install me as a judge in the land? [Then] to me would come every man who has a complaint and litigation and I will judge him righteously.”
5. And when the man would draw near to bow down to him, he [Avsholom] would extend his hand, grab hold of him and would kiss him.
6. Avsholom did this to all of Yisroel coming for judgment to the king. [In this way] Avsholom stole the hearts of [misled] the people of Yisroel.
7. At the end of forty years, Avsholom said to the king, “I would like to go and fulfill my vows [of bringing sacrifices] that I [previously] vowed to God in Chevron [so I may fulfill them].
8. For your servant made a vow while I was staying in Geshur in Arom saying, ‘If God returns me to Yerusholayim, I will worship God [with sacrifices].’ ”
9. The king said to him “Go in peace.” He [Avsholom] got up and went to Chevron.
10. Avsholom sent spies to all the tribes of Yisroel saying “When you hear the sound of the shofar, you should say ‘Avsholom reigns in Chevron.’ ”
11. Two hundred men left with Avsholom from Yerusholayim. They were invited and went in innocence and they knew nothing [of Avsholom’s conspiracy].

12. Avsholom sent for Achitophel the Gilonite, the counsellor to Dovid, to come from his city, Giloh while they slaughtered the sacrifices. The bond [of conspiracy] strengthened. Additional people were constantly joining with Avsholom.
13. The informant came to Dovid saying, “The hearts of the men of Yisroel are behind Avsholom.”

14. Dovid said to all his servants that were with him in Yerusholayim, “Let us get up and flee because we will not be able to escape from before Avsholom. Let us hurry and leave lest he quickly overtake us and thrust evil upon us and strike the city with the sword.”
15. The king’s servants said to the king, “All that you choose [to do] my master O king, we your servants are here [with you].
16. The king and all his household left by foot. The king left behind ten concubine women to watch the house.
17. The king and all the people left by foot. They stopped far away.
18. All his servants were passing by him, all the archers, all the throwers and all the Gitites. Six hundred men that came by foot from Gat, all passing by the face of the king.
19. The king said to Itai the Gitite, “Why are you going with us? Return and stay with the king because you are a foreigner and even if you are estranged [from Avsholom] you can go to your home.

20. You [just] came yesterday and should I today cause you to move out with us. I am going to where [circumstances have] me go. Return and take back your brethren with you. I will consider it kindness and truth.”

21. Itai replied to the king and said, “As Adonoy lives and as my master the king lives, only in the place where my master the king will be whether for death or for life [that is] where your servant will be.”
22. Dovid said to Itai, “Go and pass by.” And Itai the Gitite passed by [together with] all his men and all the children that were with him.

23. All the [people of] the land were crying with a loud voice as all the people were passing by. As the king passed by Nachal Kidron all the people were passing along the width of the highway towards the desert.

24. And also Tzodok and all the Levites with him who were carrying the Ark of the convenant of God. They set down the Ark of Elokim and Evyosor went off [to the side] until all the people finished passing out of the city.
25. The king said to Tzodok, “Return the Ark of God to the city. If I find favor in Adonoy’s Eyes, He will bring me back and I will see Him and His dwelling place.
26. And if he says as follows, ‘I do not want you.’ Here I am, do unto me whatever is favorable in Your Eyes.”
27. The King said to Tzodok, the Kohein, “If you see this [as right], return to the city in peace and Achimaatz, your son and Yohonoson, the son of Evyosor your two sons with you.
28. Look, I will stay in the plains of the desert until word comes from you to tell me.”
29. Tzodok and Evyosor returned the Ark of Elokim to Yerusholoyim and they stayed there.

30. Dovid went upon the heights of Mount of Olives, crying as he went up. His head was covered and he went barefoot. All the people that were with him, each man covered his head and they went up crying as they went up.
31. Dovid was told [by an informer] saying, “Achitophel is among the conspirators with Avsholom.” Dovid said, “Adonoy, please ruin Achitophel’s advice.”
32. Dovid arrived at the summit where he used to bow down to God. Chushai, the Arkite greeted him. His tunic was tom and dirt was on his head.
33. Dovid said to him, “If you travel with me you will be a burden for me.

34. [But] if you return to the city and say to Avsholom, ‘King, I will be your servant. Previously, I was your father’s servant and now I am your servant.’ [Then] you can sabotage for me Achitophel’s advice.
35. And with you there will be Tzodok and Evyosor, the Kohanim. Everything you hear from the king’s palace, tell Tzodok and Evyosor the Kohanim.
36. Their two sons are there with them, Achimaatz for Tzodok and Yohonoson for Evyosor. “Send [messages] in their hands to me [about] all the things you hear.”
37. Chashai, Dovid’s friend came to the city and Avsholom was going to come to Yerosholoyim.

1. Dovid passed a little further beyond the summit and Zivoh, Mephivoshes’ young man greeted him with a pair of saddled donkeys. Upon them was two hundred loaves of bread, one hundred clusters of raisins, one hundred portions of dried figs and a jug of wine.

2. The king said to Tsivoh “What is your intent with these?” Tsivoh said [in reply], The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride, the bread and the dried figs are for the young men to eat and the wine is for those tired in the desert to drink.

3. The king said, “Where is your master’s son?” Tsivoh said to the king [in reply], “He is dwelling in Yerusholoyim because he is saying, ‘Today, the house of Yisroel will return to me my father’s kingdom.’ ”
4. The king said to Tsivoh, “All that belongs to Mephivoishes is [now] yours.” Tsivoh said, “I bow down [in gratitude] I should find favor in your eyes, my master the king.
5. King Dovid came to Bachurim and a man came out from there from the family of the house of Shaul and his name was Shimi, the son of Gairoh. He came out and kept on cursing.
6. He threw stones at Dovid and on all the servants of king Dovid, and all the people and all the soldiers were on his [Dovid’s] right and on his left.
7. This is what Shimi said in his cursing, “Begone, begone, man of blood and debased man.

8. Adonoy has repayed you for all the blood of the House of Shaul that you have replaced as king. Adonoy has delivered the monarchy into the hand of your son Avsholom. Here you are in a bad way because you are a man of blood.”
9. Avishai, the son of Tsruyoh said to the king, “Why is this dead dog cursing my master, the king? I will go over there and take off his head.
10. The king said [in reply], “What is between me and you sons of Tsruyoh? He should curse [me] like this because Adonoy told him ‘Curse Dovid.’ Who can say, ‘Why have you done this?’.”

11. Dovid said to Avishai and to all his servants, “Behold, my son who came forth from within me is seeking to kill me even more so a son of a Binyomite should now [rise against me]. Let him curse because Adonoy told him to do so.
12. Maybe, Adonoy will see [the tears] in my eyes, and Adonoy will bring good to me instead of his curse of this day.
13. Dovid and his men went on the path and Shimi went along the side of the mountain opposite him cursing as he went and throwing stones at him and throwing dirt.
14. The king and all the people with him came [to Bachurim] exhausted and they rested there.
15. Avsholom and all the people, men of Yisroel came to Yerusholoyim and Achitophel with him.
16. When Chushai the Arkite, Dovid’s friend came to Avsholom, Chushai said to Avsholom, “The king should live, the king should live.”
17. Avsholom said to Chushai, “This is your kindness towards your friend? Why did you not go with your friend?”
18. Chushai said to Avsholom, No, because to whom God has chosen along with this people and all men of Yisroel with him I will be and with him I will dwell.
19. Secondly, whom am I serving? Is it not before his [own] son? As I have served before your father so too I will be before you.”
20. Avsholom said to Achitophel, “You [wise men] give [me] advice concerning what to do [next].”

21. Achitophel said to Avsholom, “Lie with your father’s concubines that he left to watch the palace and all of Yisroel will hear that you have disgraced your father and you will [thereby] strengthen the hands of all those who are with you.
22. They pitched a tent on the roof for Avsholom and Avsholom laid with his father’s concubines before the eyes of all Yisroel.
23. The counsel of Achitophel that he counselled in those days [was as trustworthy] as inquiring of the word of God. So was the advice of Achitophel, both for Dovid and [later] for Avsholom.
1. Achitophel said to Avsholom, “Let me choose twelve thousand men and I will arise and pursue after Dovid tonight.”
2. I will reach him [when] he will be tired and weak. I will frighten him [suddenly] and all the people with him will flee and I will strike [only] the king himself.
3. I will return all the people to you. When they all return [to you] [except] the man you want [killed] [then] all the people will have peace.
4. The idea was favorable in Avsholom’s eyes and in the eyes of all of the elders of Yisroel.
5. Avsholom said, “Call Chushai the Arkite also and let us hear what he has to say.”
6. Chushai came to Avsholom and Avsholom said to him, saying, “Achitophel said such and such, should we do as he said or not? you tell [us].”
7. Chushai said to Avsholom, “The advice is not good that Achitophel has given this time.”

8. Chushai said, “You know your father and his men that they are strong and they are embittered souls like a bear bereft of it’s children [fighting] in the field. Your father is a man of war and he will not rest with the people.

9. Now, he is hiding in one of the pits or one of the places [to hide]. When some of the men fall at the beginning [of their battles], a person will hear and will say, ‘There was a disaster amongst the people that follow after Avsholom.’
10. Even if he is a soldier who has a heart like that of a lion, his heart will surely melt because all of Yisroel knows that your father is strong as are the soldiers that are with him.
11. But I advise [as follows:], Gather unto you all of Yisroel from Dan to Be’er Sheva a multitude like the sand by the sea and you yourself should go to war.

12. We will reach him in one of the places where he will be found and we will encamp upon him as the dew falls on the ground and there will be none left, not of him nor of any of the men with him [not] even one.
13. And if they gather into a city [then] all of Yisroel should go up to that city in groups. We will drag [the city wall] into the valley [below] until not even a pebble will be found there.

14. Avsholom and all the men of Yisroel said, “Chushai the Arkite’s advice is better then Achitophel’s advice.” Adonoy commanded to annul the good advice of Achitophel in order for Adonoy to bring evil upon Avsholom.
15. Chushai said to Tzodok and to Evyosor the Kohanim, “Such and such Achitophel advised Avsholom and the elders of Yisroel and I advised [him] such and such.

16. And now, send [messengers] quickly and tell Dovid saying, ‘Do not rest tonight in the plains of the desert, but cross over it, because [my suggestion] may be rejected by the king and all the people with him.

17. Yahonoson and Achima’atz were standing by the launderers’ fountain, and the handmaiden used to go and tell them and they went and told King Dovid because they could not [let themselves] be seen by coming into the city.
18. A young man saw them and told Avsholom. They went quickly and came to a man’s house in Bachurim and he had a well in his courtyard and they descended into it.
19. The woman took [a curtain] and spread the curtain over the face of the well and she spread ground wheat on it and the matter did not become known.

20. Avsholom’s servants came to the woman’s house and said, “Where are Achima’atz and Yehonoson?” The woman said [in reply], “They crossed over the stream of water.” They searched [but] did not find [them] and returned to Yerusholoyim.

21. After they [Avsholom’s servants] left they climbed up from the well and went and told King Dovid. They said to Dovid, “Rise and quickly cross over the water for such has Achitophfelophel advised against you.”
22. Dovid rose together with all the people with him and they crossed over the Yardein. By the light of the morning. not one [person] was missing who did not cross over the Yardein.

23. Achitophel saw that his advice was not put into action. He saddled his donkey, got up and went to his house [in] his city. He gave [his last] instructions to his family. He [then] strangled himself and died. He was buried in his father’s grave.
24. Dovid came to Machanoyim [as] Avsholom crossed the Yardein, he and all the men of Yisroel with him.

25. Avsholom put Amosoh [at the head] of the army in place of Yoav. Amosoh was the son of a man, whose name was Yisrah the Yisroelite who had relations with Avigal, the daughter of Nochosh, [who was] the sister of Tsruyoh, the mother of Yoav.
26. [The men of] Yisroel and Avsholom encamped in the land of Gilod.
27. When Dovid came to Machanoyim, [he met] Shovi, the son of Nochosh from Rabbahs of the people of Amon and Mochir, the son of Amiel from Lo Devor and Barzilai, the Gilodite from Roglim.
28. [They brought] mats, and basins earthenware utensils, wheat, barley flour, toasted grain, beans, lentils toasted lentils,
29. honey, butter, sheep and cow’s cheese they brought to Dovid and to the people with him to eat because they said, “The people are hungry, tired and thirsty in the desert.”
1. Dovid numbered the people that were with him and appointed over them officers [to lead] thousands and officers [to lead] hundreds.

2. Dovid sent the people forth, a third under the hand of Yoav, a third under the hand of Avishai, the son of Tsruyoh, Yoav’s brother and a third by the hand of Itai, the Gitite. The king said to the people, “I will also go out with you.”

3. The people said [in reply], “Do not go out [with us] because if we flee they will not pay us any attention and if they kill half of us they will not pay us any attention because now [you are worth] ten thousand of us. And now, it will be better if you help us from the city.”
4. The king said to them, “I will do as you see fit.” The king stood off to the side of the gate and all the people went forth, by hundreds and by thousands.
5. The king commanded Yoav, Avishai and Itai saying, “Be gentle to the young man, Avsholom for me.” All the people heard the king’s order to all the officers concerning Avshalom.
6. The people went out to the field against [the army of] Yisroel. The battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.
7. The army of Yisroel was defeated there by the servants of Dovid. There was a great slaughter there on that day of twenty thousand [men lost].
8. The war spread all over the land, The [wild beasts of the] forest killed more people than the sword devoured on that day.

9. Avsholom chanced to meet the servants of Dovid and Avsholom was riding on a mule. The mule passed under the branches of a great elm tree and his head got caught in the elm tree. He was hanging between the sky and the earth and the mule that was under him passed on by.
10. A man saw this and told it to Yoav and said, “I saw Avsholom hanging from an elm tree.”
11. Yoav said to the man who told him, “You saw him, why did you not strike him to the ground and I would have given you ten silver peices and one belt.”

12. The man said to Yoav, “Had I been able to take a thousand silver peices, I would not have hurt the king’s son because [we heard] with our own ears that the king commanded you, Avishai and Itai saying, ‘Beware that none harm the young man, Avsholom’.
13. Had I tried to lie [and cover up his murder], nothing would [remain] concealed from the king and you would distance yourself [from me].”
14. Yoav said, “I will not ask you [any further].” He took three spears in his hand and thrust them through Avsholom’s heart while he was still alive in the midst of the elm tree.
15. Ten young men, who carried Yoav’s weapons gathered around, They struck Avsholom and killed him.
16. Yoav blew the shofar and his people stopped chasing after [the army of] Yisroel. because Yoav restrained his people.
17. They took Avsholom, threw him into a big ditch in the forest, and piled up a great heap of stones on top of it. All the men of Yisroel fled to their homes.

18. Avsholom had taken and built for himself a monument during his lifetime, which is in the king’s valley because he said, “I have no son, this will memorialize my name.” He named the monument after himself calling it, “the place of Avsholom.” [It remains] until today.
19. Achima’atz, the son of Tsodok said, “I shall run and inform the king that Adonoy has punished his enemies.”
20. Yoav said to him, “You are not to inform him today, but you shall inform him another day but do not announce it today because the king’s son is dead.”
21. Yoav said to the Kushite, “Go tell the king what you saw.” The Kushite bowed to Yoav and ran off.

22. Achima’atz, the son Tsodok again asked and said to Yoav, “come what may please let me run after the Cushite [to inform the king as well].” Yoav replied, “Why should you run, my son there is no reward in this announcement for you.”
23. “Come what may, I will run.” And he [Yoav] said to him, “Run.” Achima’atz ran by way of the plain and he passed the Kushite.
24. Dovid was sitting between the two gates and the lookout went up to roof of the gate on top of the wall. He looked out and saw that there was a man running alone.
25. The lookout called out and told the king. The King said, “If he is alone, he must be a messenger.” He came closer and closer.
26. The lookout saw another man running. The lookout called the gate guard and said, “There is a man running alone.” The King said, “This is also a messenger.”
27. The lookout said, “I recognize the first man’s running as being the runing of Achima’atz, the son of Tsodok.” The king said, “This is a good man and he is coming with good news.”

28. Achima’atz called out and said to the king, “All is well.” He bowed to king with his face to the ground, and said, “Blessed is Adonoy your God that has delivered [into Yoav’s hands] those men who rebelled against my master, the king.”

29. The King said, “Is it well with the young man, Avsholom?” Achima’atz replied, “I saw a great multitude [engaged in battle] when Yoav sent one of the king’s other servants and [me] your servant and I do not know what [happenned afterwords].”
30. The king said, “Move over there and stand there.” He moved over there and stood there.
31. The Kushite arrived and the Kushite said, “Let it be announced [to all], my master, the king that today God has punished all those who have risen up against you.”

32. The king said to the Kushite, “Is it well with the young man, Avsholom?” The Kushite replied, “May they [die] as did the young man [those who] are enemies of my master, the king as should all those who have risen up against you.”

1. The king began to tremble and went up to the room over the gate and wept. And this is what he said as he went, “My son Avsholom. My son, my son Avsholom. If only I had died instead of you. Avsholom my son, my son.
2. It was told to Yoav that the king was crying and mourning over Avsholom.
3. The victory of that day was turned into mourning for all of the people because the people heard on that day saying, “The king grieves over his son.”
4. On that day the people entered the city discreetly like people silent and ashamed from having fled from battle.
5. The king covered his face and the king cried out loudly, “My son Avsholom, Avsholom my son, my son.

6. Yoav came inside the king’s chamber and said, “Today, you have embarassed all your servants who have, this day, saved your life and the lives of your sons and daughters, the lives of your wives and the lives of your concubines.

7. You are showing love to your enemies and hatred towards your friends for [by your actions] today you are declaring that you do not value your officers or servants. For today I know that [you are thinking] if only Avsholom were alive and all of us dead, it would have been right in your eyes.

8. Now, get up, go out and speak to the hearts of your servants because I have sworn by Adonoy that [if] you do not go out [to the people] then no one will remain here with you tonight. This will be worse for you then all the evil that has befallen you from your youth up until today.”
9. The king rose, [went] and sat by the gate. All the people were told, “The king is sitting by the gate.” All the people came before the king [as the people of] Yisroel fled back to their homes.

10. All the people reproached each other throughout all the tribes of Yisroel, saying. “The king saved us from the hands of our enemies and he saved us from the hands of the Pelishtim, now he has had to flee from the land because of Avsholom.
11. Avsholom whom we anointed king over us, has died in battle. And now, why are you silent about restoring the king [to his throne].”

12. King Dovid sent [messages] to Tsodok and Evyosor the Kohanim saying, “Speak to the elders of Yehudah saying, “Why should you be last to bring back the king to his palace while the messages of all Yisroel are coming to the king [requesting his return] to his palace.
13. You are my brothers, you are of my own flesh why should you be the last to bring back the king.’
14. And tell Amosoh [in my name], ‘are you not of my own bone and flesh. God should do [such and such] to me and more if I do not make you my commanding officer from now on, instead of Yoav.’
15. He [Dovid] was able to sway the hearts of all the men of Yehudah [to favor him] as one would sway just one man. They sent [a message] to the king, ‘You and all your servants should return.’
