16. The king began his return and as he reached the Yardein, Yehudah came to Gilgal to greet the king to bring the king over the Yardein.
17. Shimi, the son of Geiroh, hurried, [son] of the Yemini from Bachurim, and went down with the men of Yehudah to greet king Dovid.
18. A thousand men from Binyomin accompanyed him together with Tzivoh, a young man from the house of Shaul and his fifteen sons and twenty servants. They crossed the Yardein before the king.
19. The ferry boat crossed over bringing the household of the king and to what is good in his eyes. Shimi, the son of Geiroh fell before the king as he crossed the Yardein.

20. He said to the king, “Do not consider it a sin on my behalf, do not remember how your servant wronged [you] on the day my master, the king left Yerusholoyim. The king [should not] take it to heart.
21. Because your servant knows that I have sinned, behold I come today the first from among all the House of Yoseif to come down and greet my master the king.
22. Avishai, the son of Tsruyoh replied and said, Should Shimi not be put to death for this since he cursed the anointed one of Adonoy?

23. Dovid said, “What [hatred] exists between me and you, sons of Tsruyoh that today you should be adversaries unto me? Should a man of Yisroel die today? Because I [now] know that today I am [truly] king over Yisroel.
24. The king said to Shimi, “You shall not die.” And the king swore unto him.

25. Mephivoshes, the son of Shaul went down to greet the king. He had not tended to the hair [between] his legs nor groomed his moustache nor laundered his clothes from the day the king left until his peaceful return.
26. When he came to Yerusholoyim to the greet the king, the king said to him, “Why did you not go with me, Mephivoshes?”

27. He replied, “My master the king, my servant [Tsivoh] deceived me because your servant said [to Tsivoh], ‘Saddle up the donkey so that I can ride it and join the king’, because your servant is lame.
28. And he [Tsivoh] maligned your servant to my master the king. My master the king is like an angel of God, do what you deem to be proper.

29. The entire house of my father were nothing but mortal enemies to my master the king and [nevertheless] you placed your servant among those eating at your table. What more charity can I [ask of you]? About what more can I cry to the king?”
30. The king said to him, “Why speak any further, I have said that you and Tsivoh should divide the field.”
31. Mephivoshes said to the king, “Let him take everything now that my master the king has returned to his palace in peace.”
32. Birzilai the Gilodite came down from Roglim and crossed the Yardein with the king accompanying him over the Yardein.
33. Barzilai was very old, eighty years of age, he had provided for the king during his stay in Machanayim because he was a very great man.
34. The king said to Barzilai, “You cross over with me and I will provide for you [while you stay] with me in Yerusholoyim.”
35. Barzilai said to the king, “How many more years of life [do I have] that I should go up with the king to Yerusholoyim?

36. I am eighty years old today, can I differentiate between something good or bad? Does your servant taste what I eat or what I drink? Can I still hear the voices of princes and princesses? Why should you servant remain a burden to my master the king?”
37. Your servant will just cross over the Yardein to accompany the king. Why should the king give me this type of reward?

38. Let your servant return and I will die in my own city [and be buried] in the burial place of my father and mother and your servant Kimhom will travel on with my master, the king and do unto him as you see fit.”
39. The king said, “Kimhom will cross over with me and I will do unto him what you see fit and whatever you choose, [to request] of me, I will do for you.”
40. All the people crossed the Yardein and the king crossed over. The king kissed Barzilai and blessed him. He [then] returned home.
41. The king went over to Gilgol and kimhon went over with him. All the people of Yehudah, brought the king over together with half of the people of Yisroel.

42. [Then] all the men of Yisroel came to the king and they said to the king, “Why did our brothers, steal you away the men of Yehudah and [secretly] cross the king and his household over the Yardein together with all of Dovid’s men?”
43. All the men of Yehudah answered to the men of Yisroel, “Because the king is close to us, why should this anger you? Have we received any food from the king, have any presents been given to us?”

44. The men of Yisroel replied to men of Yehudah, and said, “We have ten parts of the king and we also have more right in Dovid than you. Why have you made light of me? Was I not first in asking to have my king return?” The words of men of Yehudah overpowered the words of the men of Yisroel.

1. There, a wicked man invited [men to join him]. His name was Shevah, the son of Bichri a man of Yemini. He blew the shofar and said, “We have no part of Dovid, we have no inheritance with the son of Yeshai. Yisroel, every man should return to his home.
2. All of the men of Yisroel abandoned Dovid to follow Shevah, the son of Bichri. The men of Yehudah stayed with their king [as he travelled] from the Yardein to Yerusholoyim.

3. Dovid came to his palace in Yerusholoyim, he took the ten women who were concubines that he had left behind to watch the palace and placed them in a guarded house and provided for them [there]. He had no relations with them, and they were guarded [there] until the day of their deaths They became widows whose husband was alive.
4. The king said to Amosoh, Rally the men of Yehudah and have them here within three days and then you be back here [to meet me].
5. Amosoh went to rally Yehudah but was delayed past the appointed time that had been set.
6. Dovid said to Avishai, “Shevah, son of Bichri will do us more harm then Avsholom did. Take your master’s servants and pursue him lest he find fortified cities to escape out of our sight.
7. Yoav’s men went out after him, the archers and the slingers and all the strong soldiers. They left Yerusholoyim to pursue Shevah, the son of Bichri.

8. When [Yoav and his men] were by the great stone which is in Givon Amosoh came before them. Yoav was girded with a belt on his garment and a sword was fastened on it [the belt]. He wore it close to his loins in its sheath, and as he went towards Amosoh, it fell out.
9. Yoav said to Amosoh, “How are you, my brother?” Yoav grabbed Amosoh’s beard with his right hand to kiss him.

10. Amosoh was not watching out for the sword that was in Yoav’s hand. He [Yoav] struck him with it into his fifth rib. and his insides poured out unto the ground, and he did not strike him again, for he died [instantly]. Yoav and his brother Avishai [then] chased after Sheva, the son of Bichiri.
11. One of Yoav’s young men stood by [the corpse] and said, “Whoever likes Yoav and whoever sides with Dovid should [follow] after Yoav.

12. Amosoh was rolling in [his own] blood in the road. The man saw that the people stood in their places and [so] he removed Amosoh from the road out to the field and threw a cloth over it when he saw that all who passed by it remained there.
13. When it was withdrawn from the road all the men followed Yoav to oursue Shevah, the son of Bichri.
14. He [Shevah] went through all the tribes of Yisroel, to Oveil, Beis Ma’achoh and all the Beirim. They [Yoav’s men] gathered together and went after him.

15. They came and beseiged him in Oveil and Beis Ma’achoh They piled up an earthen mound against the city and it [the city] held by virtue of its inner wall. All the people with Yoav battered the wall to throw it down.
16. A wise woman called out from the city, “Listen, listen. Tell Yoav, ‘Come here so that I may speak to you.’.”
17. He came to her and the woman said, “Are you Yoav?” He replied, “It is I.” She said to him, “Listen to the words of your handmaiden.” He said, “I am listening.”
18. She spoke saying, “You should have talked [peace] first, if you had asked [for peace] with Oveil they would have completely [cooperated].”

19. “I am [from the people of the city] that are loyal [and] trustworthy to Yisroel, You are seeking to annhilate a city that is a metropolis of Yisroel. Why destroy the portion that Adonoy [gave to us]?”
20. Yoav replied, and said, “Far be it, far be it from me that I would devour and I would destroy.

21. That is not the case because it is a man from Har Ephraim, whose name is Shevah, the son of Bichri, has lifted up his hand against king Dovid. Give him alone to us and we wil go away from the city.” The woman said to Yoav, “His head will be thrown to you over the wall.”

22. The woman came [and spoke] to all the people with her [persuasive] wisdom. They cut off the head of Shevah, the son of Bichri and threw it to Yoav: He blew the trumpet and they disengaged from the city and dispersed, each man returning to his home. Yoav returned to Yerusholoyim to the king.
23. Yoav commanded the entire army of Yisroel. Venoyoh, the son of Yehoyodoh was [in charge of] the archers and the slingers.
24. Adorom [was put in charge] over taxes. Yehoshophot, the son of Achilud was the chronicler.
25. Shov was the scribe and Tsodok and Evyosor were the chief Kohanim.
26. Eiroh the Yoiri was also a Kohein for Dovid.

1. There was a famine during the days of Dovid, that lasted for three years, year after year [consecutively]. Dovid asked (Hashem) [why has this occurred]. (Adonoy) said, “On account of Shaul and his bloody House because he killed the Givonim.”

2. The king called the Givonim and spoke to them [words of apppeasement]. The Givonim were not part of the Bnei Yisroel but were a remnant of the Emorites. The Bnei Yisroel had sworn to them [that they would let them live]. Shaul wanted to kill them in his zeal to avenge the Bnei Yisroel and Yehudah.
3. Dovid said to the Givonim, “What can I do for you? How can I atone [for your greivances], so that you should bless the heritage of Adonoy?”

4. The Givonim replied to him, “We are not interested in silver or gold from Shaul or from his household and we are not interested in killing anyone from Yisroel.” He [Dovid] said, “What are you saying I should do for you?”
5. They replied to the king, “The man who stopped us and intended to destroy us [preventing us] from establishing ourselves throughout the boundaries of Yisroel.
6. Give us seven of his sons and we will hang them before Adonoy in Givas Shaul, the chosen one of Adonoy.” The king said, “I will give [them to you]”.
7. The king had pity on Mephivoshes, the son of Yohonoson, the son of Shaul because of the oath before Adonoy that was made between Dovid and Yohonoson, the son of Shaul.

8. The king took the two sons of Ritzpoh the daughter of Ayoh who had bore them to Shaul, [whose names were] Armoni and Mephivoshes, and [also] the five sons of Michal, the daughter of Shaul who had bore them to Adriel, the son of Birzilai, the Mecholtite.

9. He Delivered them to the hands of the Givonim and they hung them in the mountain before Adonoy. The seven were killed [all] at the same time. They were killed during the first days of the harvest, at the beginning of the barley harvest.

10. Ritzpoh, the daughter of Ayoh took a sackcloth and spread it out for herself on the mountain [where the corpses were]. [She stayed there] from the beginning of the harvest until the rains fell on them [the corpses] from heaven. She did not let any birds rest on them during the day nor any beasts of the field during the night.
11. Dovid was told what Ritzphoh, the daughter of Ayoh did; she was the concubine of Shaul.

12. Dovid went and took the bones of Shaul and the bones of Yohonoson, his son from the leaders of Yoveish Gilod who had stolen them from the street of Beis Shan. where they had hung them—the Pelishtim. on the day the Pelishtim killed Shaul in Gilboa.
13. He brought up the bones of Shaul and the bones of Yohonoson, his son and they gathered the bones that were hanging.

14. They buried the bones of Shaul and the bones of Yohonoson, his son in the land of Binyomin, in Tzailoh, in the grave of his father Kish. They did everything that the king had commanded. After that, God accepted the plea of the land
15. There was another war of the Pelishtim with Yisroel. Dovid and his servants went down and waged war against the Pelishtim and Dovid became exhausted.
16. Isho Benov, who was one of children of the giant and who had a spear case weighing three hundred bronze weights and who was armed with a new sword, said he was going to kill Dovid.

17. Avishai, the son Tsruyoh [came] to his aid, and struck the Peleshti and killed him. At that time, Dovid’s men swore to him saying, “You shall no longer go out to war with us so that the light of Yisroel not become extinguished.
18. Afterwards, there was more war with the Pelishtim in Gov. At that time, Sivkai the Chushosi struck down Sof, who was one of the giant’s children.

19. There was more war with the Pelishtim in Gov. and Elchonon, the son of Yari [whose family] were weavers in Beis Lechem, struck down Golias the Gitite, the wood part of his spear was like that of the weaver’s rod.
20. There was another war in Gas and there was a giant man whose fingers and toes numbered six each for a total number of twenty-four. He also was a child of Horopho’s.
21. He cursed Yisroel and Yohonoson killed him, [Yohonoson was] the son of Shimi, Dovid’s brother.
22. These four [giants] were born to Horophoh in Gas and they [eventually] fell into the hands of Dovid and in the hands of his servants.
1. Dovid spoke to Adonoy the words of this song. on the day Adonoy saved him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Shaul.
2. He said, Adonoy is my Rock, my Fortress and my Rescuer.
3. My God is my Rock I take refuge in Him. He is my Shield and the horn of my salvation. My Stronghold, my Refuge, my Saviour. He saved me from [all] violence.
4. I call to Adonoy in praise and I am saved from my enemies.
5. Death’s destruction surrounded me, the deluge of wicked soldiers alarmed me.
6. Groups of evil men surrounded me, death traps were before me.
7. In my distress I called to Adonoy, and to my God I called. He hears my voice from His abode, and my cries reach His ears.
8. The world shook and shuddered, the pillars of heaven trembled. They shook when God became angry:
9. Smoke rose from His nostrils, fire from His mouth consumed [the wicked]. Coals flamed forth from Him.
10. He bent heaven and descended and clouds of darkness were beneath His feet.
11. He rode on a cherub and flew, He was seen on wings of wind.
12. He put [a protective] darkness around His shelter, abundant waters, thick clouds of the sky.
13. From the brightness before Him burning coals of fire [came forth].
14. Adonoy thundered from heaven, and the most high made His voice heard.
15. He shot arrows and scattered [the enemy] [He sent forth] lightning and terrified them.
16. The bed of the ocean appeared, and the foundations of the earth were revealed by Adonoy’s [commanding] shout, by the wind blowing from His nostrils.
17. He delivers [salvation] from on high, He took me away [from my enemies]. He plucked me out of mighty waters.
18. He saved me from my mighty enemy, and from those who hate me for they were too powerful for me.
19. [My enemies] were after me at my low point, Adonoy was my Support.
20. He took me out and delivered me, He saved me because He found me favorable.
21. Adonoy rewarded me according to my rightesnous according to the purity of my hands He compensated me.
22. Because I have kept to Adonoy’s ways and I have not wickedly forsaken my God.
23. Because all his judgments were before me, and His statutes, I did not turn from.
24. I was wholehearted with Him, and guarded myself from sinning.
25. Adonoy compensated me according to my righteous and my purity in His eyes.
26. With the devout, you are kind, with the wholehearted, You are wholehearted.
27. With the pure, You are pure, and with those who are deviant You act perversely.
28. You deliver an afflicted people And Your eyes are upon the haughty to humble them.
29. For You are my light, Adonoy and Adonoy will brighten my darkness.
30. With Your [help] I will overrun [enemy] troops, with [the aid of] my God I will scale a wall.
31. God Whose way is perfect, the word of Adonoy is refined. He is the shield of all those who seek refuge in Him.
32. For who is mighty other then Adonoy? And who is a Protector other then our God?
33. The Almighty who empowered me with strenght and cleared my path to perfection.
34. He made my feet like [those of] deer and placed me on the heights.
35. He trained my hands for war, my arms to bend a copper bow.
36. You have given me the sheild of Your redemption, and Your humility has made me great.
37. You have expanded my stride beneath me and [nevertheless] my ankles did not slip.
38. I have pursued my enemies and destroyed them and I did not return until they were consumed.
39. I have consumed them, I will strike them and they will not get up. and they fell beneath my feet.
40. You infused me with strength for the battles, You caused my enemies to fall beneath me.
41. And regarding my enemies You gave me the back of their necks I cut down those who hate me.
42. They cried out but there was no one to deliver them [they cried] to Adoonoy but He did not answer them.
43. I crushed them like the dust of the earth, like the mud in the streets I ground them, I trampled them.
44. You rescued me from the antagonists among my people. You preserved me to be a leader of nations, A people that I did not [even] know serves me.
45. Foreign people lied to me [as soon] as their ears hear [my wish] they listen to [and obey] me.
46. Foreign people will wither, and become lame from [the agony of] their inprisonment.
47. Adonoy lives, and blessed is [protecting] Rock, and exalted is God, my (Rock) and my Saviour.
48. Almighty, Who avenges me [of my enemies] and subdues peoples beneath me.
49. You extract me from my enemies’ [clutches], You lift me above those who rise against me. You save me from violent men.
50. Therefore I will laud You, Adonoy, among the nations and I will sing to Your Name.
51. He delivers great salvation to His king, and bestows kindness upon His anointed one, to Dovid and his children for eternity.
1. These are the last words of Dovid the sayings of Dovid, the son of Yeshai. and the sayings of the man raised on high the annointed of the God of Yakov and he who composed sweet songs for Yisroel.
2. The spirit of Adonoy speaks through me and His word is on my tongue.
3. The God of Yisroel spoke, the Rock of Yisroel said to me ‘A ruler over men, will be a righteous person, that rules in the fear of God.
4. As day breaks with the sun shining, on a cloudless morning. [Brighter] then the light that comes from rain [falling on] vegetated earth.

5. For is not my house with God? For He has made an eternal convenant with me, perfectly arranged and preserved. All my deliverance and desires [are before God] because [my kingdom] will never be outgrown.
6. The wicked’s [kingdoms] are all like an itinerant thorn unable to be held in one’s hand.
7. Any man [wanting] to touch them must be armed with iron and with the handle of a spear. They will be completely burnt, totally consumed by the fire.

8. These are the names of the mighty men that were with Dovid. The man who sat in the council of wisdom, who was unique in three areas was Adino the Etzonite. He killed eight hundred men in one [battle].

9. After him was Elozor, the son of Dodo, the son of Achochi, one of the three mighty men that were with Dovid when they humiliated the Pelishtim who had gathered there for war, and the men of Yisroel were gone away.

10. He got up and struck the Pelishtim until his hand tired and his hand stuck to the sword. Adonoy brought great salvation on that day. The [rest of the] people returned after him but only to strip [the corpses].

11. After him was Shamoh, the son of Ogaih from the mountain. The Pelishtim gathered and assembled in troops. There was a field there, which was full of lentils, and the people fled from before the Pelishtim.
12. He [Shamoh] stood in this field and saved it. and he struck the Pelishtim. And Adonoy brought a great salvation.
13. Three of the thirty leaders went down and came to Dovid at harvest time. at the Adulom cave The assembled Pelishtim were camped in the Rephoim valley.
14. Dovid was then in the fortress and a contingent of Pelishtim was then in Beis Lechem.
15. Dovid desired [something] and said, “Who will give me water to drink from the well of Beis Lechem that is at the gate?”

16. The three warriors broke into the Pelishtim camp and drew water from the well of Beis Lechem that is at the gate. They took it and brought it to Dovid but he did not want to drink and [instead] he offered it as a libation to Adonoy.
17. he said, “Far be it from me, Adonoy, to do this. [Do I want] the blood of [these] who risked their lives?” therefore he did not drink [the water]. This is what these three warriors did.
18. And Avishai, the brother of Yoav, the son of Tsruyoh was the leader of the three. He swung his spear and killed three hundred men. His name was best known of the three.
19. Of the three, he was most honored and was their leader but he did not reach [the status] of the first three.

20. And Venoyohu, the son of Yehoyodoh the son of a warrior, a man of mighty deeds from Kabtzel. He struck down the two Moabite giants and he went down and struck the lion in the well on [that] snowy day:

21. He struck the Egyptian man, a man of [frightening] countenance, and there was a spear in the Egyptian’s hand. He [Venoyohu] went down to him [armed] with a stick and stole the spear out of the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear.
22. These things did Benoyohu, the son of Yehoydoh do, his name was best known of the three warriors.
23. Most honoured of the thirty but he did not reach [the status] of the first three. Dovid made him his aide.
24. Asoel, Yoav’s brother [was one] of the thirty [as was] Elchonon, the son of Dodo [from] Beis Lochem.
25. Shamoh the Charodite, Elikoh the Charodite.
26. Cheletz the Paltite, Iroh, the son of Ikeish, the Tokite
27. Aviezer the Ansosite, Mevunai the Chushosite.
28. Tsalmon the Achochite Mahary the Netophosite.
29. Cheilev, the son Ba’anoh the Netophosite, Itai, the son of Rivai from the valley of Bnai Binyomin.
30. Benoyohu the Pirosonite, Hidai from Nachalei Goash.
31. Avi Alvon the Arvosite, Azmoves, the Barchumite.
32. Elyachboh the Sha’alvonite, Yoshain’s son, Yehonoson.
33. Shamoh the Havorite, Achiom, the son of Shoror the Arorite.
34. Eliphelet, the son of Achasbuy the son of the Machosite, Eliom, the son of Achitophel the Gilonite.
35. Chetzry the Carmelite, Pa’ary the Arbite.
36. Yigol, the son of Noson from Tzovoh, Boni the Godite.
37. Tzelek the Amonite [and] Nachrai the Be’erosite the weapons carriers of Yoav, the son of Tsruyoh.
38. Iroh the Yisrite, Goreiv the Yirite.
39. Urioh the Chitite, [these are] all thirty-seven.
1. Adonoy’s anger was again kindled against Yisroel. he enticed Dovid against saying, “Go, count Yisroel and Yehudah.”

2. The king said to Yoav the general of the army that was with him, “Go to all the tribes of Yisroel from Don until Be’er Shevah and number the people [in order] that I should be able to know, the count of the people.”

3. Yoav said to the king, “Adonoy your God should add to the people one hundred times their [current] number, and may my master the king’s eyes see it. [But] my master the king, why do you want such a thing?”
4. The king’s word overrode Yoav and the army officers. Yoav and army officers left the king’s presence to count the people of Yisroel.
5. They crossed the Yardein and they camped in Aroeir, to the right of the city which was in the valley of to Gad. [From there they went] unto Yazer.
6. They came to Gilod and to a land of a new [settlement]. They came to Don’s portion, to Ya’an and [then] around Tsidon.
7. They came to a mountain fortress and all the Chivite and Canaanite cities, they [then] went out to southern Yehudah to Be’er Shovah.
8. They went all over the land and they came at the end of nine months and twenty days to Yerusholoyim.
9. Yoav gave the sum of the people’s census, to the king, and there were in Yisroel eight hundred thousand valiant men armed with swords and the men of Yehudah were five hundred thousand men.

10. Dovid’s heart pained him that he had counted the people. Dovid said to Adonoy, “I have gravely sinned by what I have done. Now Adonoy, let the sin of your servant pass for I have been very foolish.”
11. Dovid rose in the morning and the word of Adonoy came to the prophet Gad, Dovid’s seer, saying:
12. “Go tell Dovid that thus Adonoy has said, ‘I will afflict you with [one of] three [things], choose one of them and I will do it to you’.”

13. Gad came to Dovid and told him. He said to him, “Do you want seven years of famine to come in your land or to flee from your enemy for three months and he will pursue you or to have three days of pestilence in your land? Now, think clearly what I should answer to the [One] who has sent me with this message,”
14. Dovid said to Gad, “I am in great anguish. Let us fall into the hand of Adonoy because He has much compassion, [but] let me not fall into the hands of man.”
15. Adonoy inflicted a pestilence upon Yisroel from the morning until the appointed time. And there died from the people from Don to Be’er Shevah, seventy thousand men.

16. The angel stetched forth his hand to destroy Yerusholoyim and Adonoy decided against further evil and said to the angel, that destroyed the people, “It is enough, now withdraw your hand.” The angel of Adonoy was close to the threshing floor of Aravnoh the Yevusite.

17. Dovid said to Adonoy when he saw the angel striking the people, and he said, “I have sinned, and I have acted perversely [but] this flock, what did it do? Your hand should [strike] me and my father’s house.”
18. Gad came to Dovid on that day and said to him, “Go up establish an alter for Adonoy on the threshing floor of Aravnoh, the Yevusite.”
19. Dovid went [and followed] Gad’s instructions as Adonoy commanded.
20. Aravnoh saw the king and his servant passing [near] him and Aravnoh went out and bowed down to the king with his face to the ground.

21. Aravnoh said, “Why is my master the king coming to his servant?” Dovid said, “To buy the threshing floor from you [in order] to build an altar to Adonoy [so that] the plague among the people should cease.

22. Aravnoh said to Dovid, “Take it and offer my master, the king, [whatever] is good in [your] eyes. see the cattle [fit] for a burnt offering and the rakes and the cattle equipment are [fit] for [fire] wood.
23. Aravnoh the prince gave all of this to the king and Aravnoh said to the king, “Adonoy, your God should accept your [offerings].”

24. The king said to Aravnoh, “No, I [want] to buy them from you for their value, and I will not offer to Adonoy, my God burnt offerings [obtained] for free.” Dovid bought the threshing floor and the cattle for fifty silver shekolim.
25. Dovid built an altar to Adonoy there and he offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. Adonoy was entreated of the land [people] The plague ceased from [the people of] Yisroel.

appendix.p: [[2]] Behold a man came from the camp. The Pesikta1 brings an opinion that this man is Doeig,2 but the explanation is indefensible in my heart.3

[[9]] I am gripped with convulsions. I am gripped with convulsions.4 The Midrash Aggadah5 explains that this6 occurred because of Shaul’s sin of killing the Kohanim7 as it is written concerning them,8 “a checkered shirt.”9
While I am still alive. Hurry and kill me. I prefer that you kill me and not they10 kill and torture me.11
[[10]] And the bracelet that was on his arm. The tefilin that was on his arm.12
[[16]] Your blood is on your own head. The responsibility for your death rests on your own head.13 There is no one to punish for your death but yourself.
[[18]] He said, “To teach the Bnei Yehudah archery. David said, “Now that mighty among Yisroel have fallen, the Bnei Yehudah need to be taught how to make war and how to pull back a bow.

Behold it is written in the Seifer HaYoshor. This is written in Seifer Bereishis, which is the Seifer of the righteous,14 Avraham, Yitzchok and Yaakov. And where [In Bereishis] is it hinted at? “Your hand will be on the neck of your enemies.”15 What type of warfare is it where he places his hand next to his forehead,16 which is opposite his neck?17 One must say: this is archery.
[[19]] Pillar of Yisroel, on your heights [you have been rendered] a corpse. Pillars of Yisroel, on the mightiest point of your stronghold you have fallen as corpses. This is Yonasan’s translation.
[[21]] Mountains in Gilboa. The mountains in Gilboa.
Nor fields [yielding enough for] baking offerings. There will be no harvest among [the fields] that have the amount [that necessitates] making the baking offering.18

Because there, the shield of soldiers spit out. They had shields made of skins and when they went to war, they smeared them with oil so that a weapon hitting [the shield] should slip [off of it]. As it is said [in Scriptures] “Get up officers, smear [your] shield with oil. And here this is what the Lamentation means, “There, the shield of soldiers spit out,” it spit out its oil and [the oil] did not stick to it and rendered [the shield] as if it wasn’t smeared with oil. All [uses of the word] הַגְעָלָה is a language of rejecting what had been put into it as [we find] “His oxen will impregnate, [the seed] will not be rejected.”
[[22]] Would not be pulled back. Was not used to being pulled back.19
[[23]] They were lighter then eagles. To do the will of their Creator.20
[[24]] Who has clothed you in scarlet clothing together with other delights. That clothed you in coloured garments and loaded you with delights.
[[25]] On your heights, you were slain. On your strong point you have been killed.
[[27]] The weapons of war. [Referring to] Shaul and Yohanasan who were Yisroel’s weapons.
appendix.ftnote: 1Pesikta Rabosi 12,9.
2Doeig HaEdomi is first mentioned in Shmuel 1,21:8.
3It is clear from Shmuel 1, 22:18 that Shaul knew Doeig. Therefore, if in fact this man is Doeig, why did Shaul have to ask later in v. 8, “Who are you?” (Seder Hadoros, p. 102).
4This is Targum Yonasan’s translation.
5Tanchuma Metzoro 2.
6Shaul’s death in this manner was retribution for that sin.
7Of the city of Nov, see Shmuel 1,22:18.
8The Kohanim in general.
9Vayikra, 28:4 lists the כתנת תשבץ as one of the garments worn by the Kohanim. Both the word הַּשְׁבֵּץ there and the word הַשָּׁבָץ here share the same three letters, ש־ב־ץ.
10The Pelishtim.
11Prior to my death.
12This is Targum Yonasan’s translation. He refuses to explain it to literally mean bracelet because that would have been taken by the Pelishtim as part of the spoils of war (Meam Loez).
13This is Targum Yonasan’s translation.
14Rashi is citing the opinion of Rav Yochonon in Avodah Zarah, 25a.
15Bereishis 49:8.
16When pulling back the string of his bow. Rashi in Avodah Zarah, ibid writes the archer places his hand next to his eyes. This is how they sight their targets.
17This interpretation reads the verse in Bereishis differently: “your hand will be on your neck.” See Marsho, Avodah Zarah ibid.

18If one prepares the amount of omer’s worth of dough then one must take off a portion of the mixture and give it to a kohein, see Shelach 15,20. An omer is the equivalent of forty-three and one-fifth eggs by volume.
19Without hitting Yohanasan’s targets, thereby spilling his enemies’ blood and cutting through their fat.
20Rashi is paraphrasing Pirkei Avos 5,23.

appendix.p: [[8]] Took Ish Boshes. He extrapolated from a verse that two kings were destined to come from Binyomin. Because the Holy One, blessed is He told Yakov, “Kings will come forth from you,” and [by this time] all of his children had been born except for Binyomin.1
[[16]] The Plain of Swords. Yonasan translates the plain of Killing on account of the swords just like you say [in Scriptures] (Tehilim 89, 44)2 “You also turned back the sharpness of his sword.”
[[23]] Into the fifth rib. As [if to say] the fifth rib,3 the place where the bile and the liver are set. [But] Yonasan translated [this to mean] “on the side of his thigh,”
And died in his place. And died in his place.4

[[27]] If you had not spoken. If only you had spoken this [way5 earlier] [The לא] is as [if it were written] לו6, meaning it. Another [way] to interpret it is as it’s plain meaning7: if you had not spoken i.e. that which you said “Let the young soldiers get up and playfight.”8
[[29]] The Bisron. The name of a region.

[[30]] Nineteen men and Asoel. But is not Asoel included in [the group called] “the servants of Dovid,” so why is he [singled] out? [The reason is] he was worth all of them [together] and so too [a similar case], (Yehoshua 2,1), “Go see [and spy out] the land and Yericho”9 and so too [another similar case] “King Shlomo loved many foreign women and the daughter of Pharaoh.”10 (Kings I, 11, 1 ).
appendix.ftnote: 1“Will come forth from you” implies that they were to come from someone yet unborn, and this could only be Binyomin. Avner understood this to mean that two kings will be descendant from Binyomin, Shaul and Ish Boshes (Rashi and Sifsei Chachomin, Breshis 35,11).
2Rashi is showing how the word צוּר, sharpness, is used in reference to a sword.
3Counting from the bottom.
4This is Targum Yonasan’s translation.
5Your decrying of us fighting each other.
6According to this first interpretation, the construct לוּלֵא denotes לוֹלוּ, “if only if,” i.e., if only you had spoken these reconcilitory words earlier.
7This interpretation of לולא is the usual “if not for.”
8Those words triggered this deadly battle.
9Yericho was as strong as the entire land combined (see Rashi there).
10Shlomo cherished Pharaoh’s daughter as much as he did the rest of them put together. (See Rashi ibid).

appendix.p: [[3]] His second [son] was Kilov. [But] in another place1 [Scriptures] calls him, “and his second [son] was Doniel”.2 So why is his called [here] by the name of Kilov? Rebbe Yitzchok said [to answer this question] : Because the generation’s cynics were saying that Avigail was pregnant from Novol,3 [consequently Hashem caused] his facial features to change and resemble his father.4 And our Rabbis said5 that [this name of Kilov was due to the fact that] he embarrassed Mephiboshes through Halacha.6

[[5]] By Egloh This refers to Michal7 who was cherished by him. Similarly it says “If you had not plowed with my calf” (Shoftim 14, 18).8 [But] it is written, “And Michal, the daughter of Shaul had no child until the day of her death” (Below, 6, 23) she didn’t have one until the day of her death9?10 From that incident11 and on [she had no children], but prior to that incident she did have [children].
[[6]] Was strengthening. With all his might over the house of Shaul, to establish its monarchy.

[[8]] Am I the chief dog [watcher] for [the kingdom of] Yehudah? Am I at least as important as the chief dog watcher for Dovid. However, according to the cantillation which has the accent under [the word] ראׁשׁ and [the word] כֶּלֶב אָנׂכׅי coralled [together],12 then this is the explanation: The chief? Do I want to be a chief in your house? It is better for me to be a dog and an ordinary person in the house of Dovid. This is also Yonasan’s translation.

From this day on should I [continue to] be kind. From now on [is it] proper for me to be kind to the house of Shaul and with all those who love him as I have done until now and I have not delivered you into the hand of Dovid?
[[12]] In his behalf saying. From his place to say, We shall keep this [oath] by the One Who made the world.

By He Who [posseses] the land. [This is] language [used for] an oath, By He Who [posseses] the land. Another interpretation: “Below him,” [Avner] mentioned his name first in the message letter and afterwords he mentioned Dovid’s name and that is why he was punished. [This is what] he wrote: From me, Avner, the general of Yisroel to Dovid, the king of Yisroel, peace salutation.
To He who [deserves] the land. To whom the kingdom is proper for him, I am sending to him “saying, Enact a convenant, etc.”
[[13]] You first bring. Before you see my face, bring me Michal.
[[15]] From [her] man. Yonasan translated “from the company of her husband.”

[[16]] Following and crying. Over the good deed [about to be] leaving him because all those years he thrust a sword into the bed [separating] between him and her and he did not stumble [into sinful intimacy] with her.13
[[17]] And the word of Avner was [sent] Before this [incident with Paltiel]
[[18]] Said about Dovid. About Dovid, and this is not [an instance of the usual] meaning of the word, אל, “to”.
[[22]] From an attack. They sprung, attacking to take spoils from the enemy.

[[26]] From Bor HaSiroh. The name of a place [But] the Rabbis said: A well and a thorn caused Avner to be killed, by not grasping unto the deeds of Dovid, by [ignoring] the jug of water that [Dovid] took from [under] the head of Shaul14 and also [by ignoring] the corner of Shaul’s garment15 [Avner dismissed this and] he said “Perhaps one of the thorns caught upon [the garment] and tore it.
[[27]] Within the gate. [Yoav brought Avner] before a sanhedrin to be judged16 for the [spilling of] blood of his brother, Asoel.

Deceptively. In a mistake provoking [way] so that Avner would not realize that it is in [Yoav’s] heart to kill him. Cut up the verse [to rearrange it’s words as follows] “and Yoav steered him deceptively to go within the gate to talk to him.”

[[29]] [The guilt] should fall. The [guilt of the] blood of Avner should rest, should fall. [This verse is] referring back to the preceding verse that stated, I and my kingdom are innocent from [the guilt of] the blood of Avner [The guilt of] his blood should fall on the head of Yoav. The blood [of Avner] that was mentioned in the previous verse.
[A lame person] who leans on a cane. Who leans on his cane because of diseased feet.

[[30]] Killed Avner. [As if to say] Avner17 and similar to it [we find] “Snatch me, be my surety” (Yeshaiya 38, 14), Snatch me18 and also similarly (Bamidbar 12,13), “Please heal her” Heal her19 and similarly to this (Divrei Hayomin II, 17, 7) “He sent his officers, Ben Chayil, and Ovadiah… to teach in the cities of Yehudah and it’s meaning is: He sent his officers, Ben Chayil.20
[[33]] The death of someone wicked. Like the death by sword of a wicked person.
[[34]] Your hands were not bound.21 How could a mighty soldier such as you fall before treacherous men.
[[35]] To feed. [This is] language [denoting] a meal.
[[39]] I am today weak [as a commoner] And I am, on this day, a commoner and a young king.
appendix.ftnote: 1Divrei Hayomim I, 3,1.
2i.e., refers to the second son of Dovid not as Kilov but as Doniel, his true name.
3That Doniel was the son of Novol and not Dovid.
4His resemblance to Dovid earned him the name of כִלְאָב a play on כּוּלוֹ אָב, “completely his father.”
5Berochos 4a.
6Doniel’s superior knowledge became evident during the course of his halachic debates with Mipiboshes. According to this Derosho, the letters כל of כִלְאָב stand for מַכְלׅים.
7The daughter of Shaul.
8עגלה, “calf” is used in reference to a cherished wife just as a calf is cherished by it’s owner (See Sanhedrin 21a).
9At which time she died in childbirth (ibid).
10That verse implies that Michal had no children up to the time of her death, but our verse states that Egloh, i.e. Michal gave birth to Yisrom.

11Dovid rejoiced excessively when the Ark was returned from captivity. Michal rebuked Dovid for what seemed to her to be behavior beneath his dignity. This was not the case and she was punished for the unwarranted shaming of Dovid. (ibid).

12Rashi’s first explanation is assumming that the words ראש and כלב are connected. However, the cantillation indicates that they are separate. Instead, the words כלב אנכי belong together. This compels Rashi to offer an alternative explanation.

13Shaul did not consider her married to Dovid because he considered Dovid’s Kiddushin having been done using a loan which is an invalid Kiddushin. However, in fact, Dovid had used regular material wealth as his means for Kiddushin which made Dovid halachically married to Michal. This meant that Paltiel Ben Loyish was living in the same house with another man’s wife. For all those years Paltiel made sure never to touch her and thus was spiritually elevated by subduing his lustful inclination. Now that she was leaving, he was saddenned to no longer have the opportunity for this type of spiritual greatness. (Sanhedrin, ibid).

14This is reference to Shmuel I, 26,12 where Dovid was being pursued by Shaul and Avner. Dovid found them sleeping and hence vulnerable. Not wanting to harm them but wanting to show Shaul he had been there, Dovid took the spear and the jug of water that was underneath Shaul’s head.

15This is a reference to Shmuel I, 24,5 where Shaul, in pursuit of Dovid, stopped temporarily inside the cave where Dovid was hiding with his men. Dovid did not kill him but surreptitiously caught off the corner of Shaul’s garment.
16The word שַׁעַר often refers to judges who usually hold court at the gate of the city, cf. Devorim 22,15.
17Without the ל because it is the object of the verse’s verb “killed.” Whereas Avner with the prefix ל would usually mean “to Avner.”
18Not “to me” despite the verse using the word לי.
19Not “to her” despite the verse using the word לָהּ.
20Not “to his officers, to Ben Chayil” despite the verse using the prefix ל.
21This word belong with the three hebrew words in the headline, Rashi is filling the word that’s missing from the verse, the verb “were.”

appendix.p: [[2]] Were for the son of Shaul Were for the son of Shaul similar to (Shmuel I, 13, 8) “until the time of Shmuel” of Shmuel.
[[3]] And the Be’erosites fled When Shaul died, the people of Yisroel abandoned the cities that surround the Peleshtim as is mentioned above.1 It was then that the Be’erosites fled.

[[4]] Yohanoson, the son of Shaul had. [The verses] continue to recount how the monarchy was stripped from the house of Shaul. He and his sons were killed and this one [Ish Boshes] was killed on his bed and the son of Yohanoson fell and became lame.
Broken feet Broken feet.
[[6]] They came into the interior of the house. Together with the traders, the wheat buyers.
[[10]] He thought I would reward him for his good tidings. He thought he was making me happy in order that I should reward him for his good tidings.
appendix.ftnote: 1Shmuel I, 31,7.

appendix.p: [[6]] To the Yevusi. The fortress of Tzion was called Yevus. [Its inhabitants] were from the descendants of Avimelech. They had two idols, one [depicting] a blind person and one [depicting] a lame person. They were made to represent Yitzhok and Yakov.1 [Placed] in their mouths was the oath Avrohom swore to Avimelech,2 This is why they were not displaced [from Tzion]. When Yerushalayim was conquored The tribe of Yehuda did not conquor the fortress [of Tzion], as the verse states, (Yehoshua, 15, 63). “However the Yevusim who lived in Yerushalyim, the descendants of Yehudah were unable to expel them. [About this verse] it is learned: Rebbe Yohoshua, the son of Levi said, They had the ability to [expel the Yevusim] but they were not permitted to.3
And he said to Dovid. Whoever said it,4
[The idols depicting] the blind and the lame These were their idols.
[[8]] Whoever kills the Yevusi and touches [and destroys] the towers spire Whoever kills the Yevusi and has the strength to conquor the fortress.
And [the idols of] the lame. And destroys [the idols of] the lame and the blind which were abhorrent to Dovid.
Upon which they are saying. Upon which they are saying, “The blind one and the lame one,” i.e., while the blind one and the lame one are here.

[Dovid] will not come Dovid will not come here. This is a shortened verse [because] it stated, “Whoever kills the Yevusi and touches [and destroys] the tower’s spire” but [the verse] does not explain what happens to the person [who reaches the spire]. However, in Divrei Hayomim I, 11, 6) it explains, “Whoever kills the Yevusi first will be made a chief and a prince.” Similar to this [we find]. “Therefore, whoever kills Kayin” (Bereishis 4, 14) and [that verse] does not explain what happens to the person [who kills Kayin] but from its context, it’s understood that the language conveys rebuke and anger.5

And touches [and destroys] the tower’s spire. [This word] denotes the spire of a tower because that’s where their idols were placed. [During] the days of Dovid, the generations of the oath had already passed.6

[[9]] From it’s low wall and inwards. A surrounding low wall; they would fill it up with earth, the summit of the mound would be in it’s middle, and it would slant in all directions, that is called a מלוא, and Dovid built houses on [the wall]. That low wall surrounded the fortress.
[[12]] Dovid understood. When he saw all his endeavors succeeding, and the idol worshipping kings sending him a present.
[[18]] Fanned out. They dispersed.
[[20]] Into the plain of Perotzim. The plain of Perotzim
Like water bursting over [walls]. Like water bursting over the walls edge.
[[21]] And Dovid burnt them. Dovid and his men burnt them.
[[22]] The valley of Rephaim. It is next to Yerusholoyim [as can be seen] in the book of Yehoshua (15, 8).
[[23]] From opposite the trees. From opposite the trees.
[[24]] The sound of stepping on the tops of the trees. These are angels stepping on the tops of the trees that I am sending to help you.
Then shout [war whoops]. Lift up [and bring forth] the sound of war and the fear of the sword Galfer in Old French, and similarly [we find] “A dog will not sharpen its tongue [growl].
appendix.ftnote: 1Yitzchak was blind at the end of his life (Bereshis, 27,1). Yakov was lamed during the course of his struggle with the angel (Bereishis 32,33).
2Bereishis 21,23–24.
3Because of Avrohom’s oath to Avimelech. This point is made in the Sifri, Re’ey, Piska 72. However, there it’s brought in the name of Rebbe Yehoshua, the son of Korcho.
4The speaker is unidentified, but is obviously one of the Yevusim.
5To whoever kills Kayin.

6Avimelech asked Avrohom to swear “that you will not deal falsely with me, with my son or my grandson.” These three generations had already passed when Dovid attacked the Yevusim in the fortress of Tzion.

appendix.p: [[1]] Dovid again gathered. To gather.

All the chosen men of Yisroel, thirty thousand. Because they gathered for him when they crowned him in Chevron and [therefore] this was a second gathering [for Dovid] [Scripture] herefore says, “[Dovid] again gathered.”

[[2]] From Baalei Yehuda. This is [the city of] Kiryas Yearim as it is said in Yehoshua, “and the boundary circled” and went up “to Baaloh, which is Kiryas Yearim” (Yehoshua 15:9). This also [can be found] in Divrei Hayomim, “Dovid and all Yisroel went up to Baaloh, which is Kiryas Yearim” (Divrei Hayomim I, 13:6). [The word] Baal means a plain.
Dovid arose and went from Baalei Yehuda. That gathered there to bring up the Ark from there…
Whose name is called, the name. The Ark is called a name, and what is the name? The name of Adonoy of Hosts was upon it.

[[3]] On a new wagon. [Dovid] made a mistake about something that even children at their Rebbe’s school know “Because the sacred work was [incumbent] upon them, which they had to carry on their shoulders” (Bamidbar 7:9). And because [Dovid] said, “Your statutes were songs for me in the house of my dwelling,”1 (Tehilim 119:54) he was punished to come to this,2 and [to have] Uzoh die through his hand. Therefore3 when they brought [the Ark] from the house of Oveid they brought it by shoulder as it says (Divrei Hayomim I, 15:12), “And he said to them, ‘You, the heads of households for the Levites, you and your brothers sanctify yourselves and bring up the Ark… because, the first time you did it not.4 Hashem, Elokeinu made a breach upon us because we did not consult with Him as was proper’.”5
[[4]] With the Ark of Elokim. This is a shortened verse, [it means to say] and they were coming with the Ark of Elokim.
[[5]] With all [instruments made of] cypress wood. Musical instruments manufactured from [cypress wood].

[[6]] Because the ox had [made] it slip. Because the ox had [made] it slip and had shaken it And so to is Yonasan’s translation, “because the ox had [made] it slip,” like [Onkelus] translates [the verse], “and his hand slips on the axe” [as follows:] and his hand slips on the axe.6

[[7]] Because of his mistake. Because of his mistake, he should have expounded a fortiori [as follows:] the Ark carried its own porters in the Yardein,7 isn’t it all the more so [that it is able to carry] itself.
[[10]] Oveid Edom. He was a Levite as it is wriiten in Divrei Hayomim (I, 15:24) and he was one of the gatekeepers.8

[[11]] And Hashem blessed. His wife and her eight daughters-in-law each gave birth to six children in one stomach9 as it is said, (Divrei Hayomim I, 26:5–8) “Poualti, the eigth10… sixty-two [belonging] to Oveid Edom.11
[[14]] Danced. Danced.
Linen robe. A linen robe, Foursaint in O.F. Yonasan translated, robe as Yonasan also translated “the robes of Tomor, the sister of Avsholom,” robes (Further, 13:18)
[[19]] A portion of meat. One sixth of a cow.
A jug [of wine]. A jug of wine.
[[20]] One of the riff-raff. [Targum Yonasan translates:] One of the riff-raff.
[[22]] [Had] I made light even more. Before Him [even] more then this [that] I made light of myself now.
I would be more honoured among them. They do not ridicule me but I am important in their eyes becasue of this.
[[23]] Had no child From that day on.12
appendix.ftnote: 1Hashem said to Dovid, “The words of the Torah upon which it is written, ‘Blink your eyes [and be distracted] from it and it is gone’ (Mishlei 23:5), you are calling songs?” (Sotah 35a). A song is of only temporary interest and then forgotten (Maharsho, ibid).
2Making the mistake of transporting the Ark by wagon.
3After learning from this mistake.
4Transporting the Ark on your shoulders.
5Consequently leading to our tragic mistake.
6Substituting the hebrew word וְנִדְּחָה with the Amaraic translation, וְתִתְמְרִיג denoting slipping just like he uses the same Amaraic word in our verse, i.e., מְרָגוּהִי.
7When Bnei Yisroel crossed the Yardein into the land of Yisroel as stated in Yehoshua 4:11 and explained in Sotah, ibid.
8Of the Bais HaMikdosh.
9Pregnancy.
10Child of Oveid Edom.
11See Berachos 63b.
12Prior to that day, she did have a child, Yisroam mentioned earlier (Shmuel II, 3:5), see Rashi there.

appendix.p: [[1]] And Hashem granted him rest. [Dovid] said [The condition] has been fulfilled, “And He has granted you peace from all your enemies etc.” (Devarim 12:10). What is written after [that verse]? “Let it be that the place that [Hashem, your Elokim] chooses etc.” It is now [incumbent] upon us to build the Chosen House.

[[4]] And it was on that night. Rebbe Chanina, the son of Popoh said the Holy One blessed be He said to Nosson, “The man I am sending you to is a quick one, he may hire workers and it will turn out that I [cause] him loss.1 Hurry and tell him, ‘It is not you who will build the Temple’.” Rebbe Simon says2 “The man I am sending you to is a vow maker” as it is said,3 “Who has sworn to Adonoy, vowed to the Mighty One of Yakov Surely I will not enter the shelter of my house”4 (Tehilim 132 2–3) “he may say, ‘I will not eat, I will not drink until I do this’5 and it will turn out that I [cause] him loss.6
[[6]] Within a tent and the Mishkan. The Mishkan of Shiloh had no roof, it had walls made of stone underneath and curtains on top [as its covering].
[[7]] Have I said a word. This language [conveys] astonishment, that’s why its punctuation has the Hei with a Kometz, and the Daled is soft [with a Dogesh].
[[8]] From the corral. The corral [used by] sheperds as [can be found], “the dugout dwelling of sheperds.” (Zfsaphania, 2:6).
[[9]] Like the name of great people. That is what is said [about Dovid] the shield of Dovid.7
I will destroy all your enemies. And that is why [the thought] came to your heart to build the House as it is written in the Torah.8
[[10]] I will make a place. I still want to quiet [things] that my people [should have] quiet and tranquility during the days of your son[’s reign].

[[11]] And from that day that I commanded. It is connected to what preceded it, they will no longer afflict [the people] as before, i.e., before the [days of the] Judges. And as they [also] did from the days of the Judges until now.
I will give you respite. More and more until you have respite from all your enemies.

Adonoy is telling you. Today, through me [Noson], that He will establish a monarchy for you to have your son [Shlomo] sit on your throne and he will secure the monarchy for you. And it is he [Shlomo] that will build the House
[[14]] With the rod of men. This refers to Haddad and Rozon, the son of Elyodoh.9

And with the afflictions of people. This refers to Ashmedoy who dethroned him.10 The demons are the children of Odom Horishon11 because the entire one hundred and thirty years that Odom [stayed] separated from his wife after Hevel’s death,12 the spirits would become heated [pregnant] and give birth from him.
[[18]] And sat before the Ark of Adonoy. Before the Ark.
Until this point. That You have made me king.
[[19]] Also, about the house of your servant. To have my son reign after me.

Is this anouncent [fitting] for [mere] man? A wonderment. Is it fitting to announce such to [mere] flesh and blood13 Another explanation: You have done for me as you did for Odom Horishon14 that you had shown him the future generations that were to come from him.
[[20]] What more can Dovid say to You. What more can I ask for?
You know Your servant. You have supplied me with all my needs as [it says] (Mishlei 12:10) “A righteous man knows his animal’s being.15”
[[21]] Because of Your word. To fulfill that which You told Shmuel to make me king.
And due to [the will of] Your Heart. It is Your will [that I become king] and not because I am worthy.
Of which You have informed Your servant. The announcement of which You have informed me.16
[[23]] For whom leaders went. Moshe and Aharon as it is said, (Shemos 7:1). “I have made you a judge over Pharaoh” and so too did Yonasan translate, “messengers went from before Hashem.”

To redeem for Him a people. This is what the messengers said to Yisroel, The Holy One, blessed is he sent us to redeem for Him a people, to put forth His Name and to make great [things happen] for you.

Awesome things You have done for your land after [Bnei Yisroel] left there [i.e., Egypt]. And what are the awesome things? From before Your people You expelled nations and their gods. This verse is missing [the word] “לגרש”, [however] in Divrei Hayomim (I 17:21) it explains, “To expel from before Your people that You redeemed from Egypt, nations and their gods.” [Our verse] isn’t [really] missing [this word] because from the sense conveyed as it is said, “From before Your people, nations” we understand that it means pushed and driven out.
[[28]] You are the Elokim. The ruler. The ability to fulfill [this promise] is in Your Hand.
[[29]] Desire. Desire.
appendix.ftnote: 1Because it is premature to build the Bein Hamikdash at this time.
2That Hashem said to Noson.
3Dovid about himself.
4Rashi explains in Tehilim, verse 5 that Dovid meant he will not go into his house until he finds out in which location the Beis Hamikdosh is slated to be built.
5i.e. build the Beis Hamikdash.
6Slightly different versions of the opinions of Rebbe Chanina and Rebbe Simon can be found in Yalkut Shimoni, Shmuel II, 143.

7Pesachim 117b. The “great people” referred to here are Avrohom, Yitzhok and Yakov. Just as they are mentioned in the first blessing of the Amidah, so too Dovid’s name is used in the ending of one of the Haftorah’s concluding blessings. (Rashi, ibid).
8Devarim 12:10. See Rashi on verse 1.
9Both were enemies of Shlomo, they are mentioned in Kings I, 11:14 and 23 respectively.
10Gittin 68b.
11See Yalkut Shimoni 146. The word אָדָם in the verse is taken as a reference to Odom Horishon.

12Rashi in Bereishis 4:25 says that the Odom’s separation was due to the fact that he had brought death, to the world. The Yalkut Shimoni does not mention why the separation occurred. In addition the Yalkut Shimoni tells as that it was Chava who separated herself from Odom.
13To be informed of the future.
14According to this interpretation, the word אָדָם in the verse is a reference to אָדָם הָרִאשׁוֹן.
15The verse refers to a righteous person but Rashi is drawing an analogy to Hashem’s knowing the needs of his servants.
16That my kingdom will be everlasting.

appendix.p: [[1]] Meseg Hoamoh. In Divrei Hayomim (I, 18:1) it’s written, “Dovid took Goss from the hand of the Pelishtim.” [Goss] is called Meseg Hoamoh because she was the stick that dominated all the Pelishtim. It was the king’s metropolis because we do not find [associated with] any of the Pelishtim rulers [not] with Azoh, Ashdod, Akron [nor] Ashkelon,1 a royal title. Only in reference Goss do we find [a royal title], “Akish, the king of Goss.”2
Meseg. Avillon in O.F.
Hoamoh. This is the harness made of wood.3

[[2]] Those measured with two ropes were killed. [This vengeance was] because they killed his father, his mother and his brothers as it is said, “He led them before the king of Moav.” (Shmuel I, 22:4) We do not find that they ever left from there.4
[[3]] As he went. When Haddadezer was going
To enlarge his border. As [Yonasan] translates, “To widen his border,” [Haddadezer] conquored land outside his countries border and widened his border.
[[4]] Dovid destroyed all the chariot [horses]. Because [of the verse], “He must not acquire an abundance of horses for himself”5

[With] one hundred chariot [horses] remaining. That he required for his riding entourage. [The word] chariot [refers to] four horses as it is said, (Divrei Hayomim II, 1:17) “Chariot for six hundred silver pieces and horses for one hundred and fifty.” From here we learn that a chariot refers to four horses.6

[[7]] The golden quivers. They are the quivers in which the arrows are put as you say, (Yirmeyah 51:11). “clean out the arrows, till the quivers.” All these chapters7 have been set near the chapter concerning the Beis Hamikdash8 because from all these wars [Dovid] gathered consecrated items for the needs of the House [i.e., Beis Hamikdash].

[[13]] Dovid made a name [for himself]. He buried those of Edom whom he had killed and that is a good name for Yisroel that they bury their enemies. As it says in reference to the war of Gog and Mogog, “All the people of the land will bury and this will acquire for them a name.” (Yechezkel 39:13) And how do we know that Dovid buried them? Because it says in the Book of kings (I, 11:15), “And it happened when Dovid was in Edom when Yoav, his army general went up to bury the corpses.”
Eighteen thousand. [However] in the Book of Tehilim (60:2) it says, “twelve thousand” Hence we must say [in response] that there were two battles.9
[[14]] Officers. Officers to collect the tax.

[[15]] Dovid rendered judgement… Yoav…was [commander] over the army. Dovid caused Yoav to be successful [with his command] over the army because he rendered judgment and righteousness and Yoav caused Dovid to render judgment and righteousness because he [Dovid] judged and Yoav policed and enforced on the basis [of the judgment].10 Another [reason is that] because Yoav busied himself with the battles, Dovid was not preoccupied by them and his heart was [able to be] open to judge righteously.
[[16]] Recorder [of halachic cases]. [He] announced which [case] was to come before him [Dovid] first for it to be ruled on first.

[[18]] Venoyohaa, the son of Yehoyodoh [was in charge of] the archers and the sling shooters. Yonasan translated, “Venoyoha, the son of Yehoydoh was appointed [in charge] over the archers and over the sling shooters.” [Alternatively] our Rabbis said [that the words] keraisi and plaisi refer to the Urim and Tumim.11
Were prominent [leaders]. [Yonasan translates] “They were prominent.”
appendix.ftnote: 1This a reference to the Pelishtim rulers enumerated in Yehoshua 13:3. Rashi has left out the Avites, because he relies on Rav’s opinion in Chulin 60b that Avites were from Teimon and not from the Philistine people.
2Shmuel I, 20:11.
3מֶתֶג means the reins. These are references to the control this city had over the Pelishtim.
4Yalkut Shimoni, 147.
5One of the prohibitions specific to the kings of Yisroel. (See Devorim 17:16)
6Given that a מֶרְכָּבָה fetched six hundred silver pieces, four times the one hundred and fifty cost of one horse.
7Concerning Dovid’s battles.
8Dovid’s desire to build a Beis Hamikdash for Hashem in the previous chapter (7:2) and Hashem’s subsequent response.
9With Edom. Tanchuma Devorim.

10Rashi is learning that the proximity of the verse discussing Dovid’s judgment of the people to the next verse discussing Yoav’s commanding of the army shows that these two phenomena were related. Other prominent leaders are being discussed in the subsequent verses but Yoav is mentioned first immediately after king Dovid.

11Rashi explains in Shemos 28:30 that this is a reference to the inscription of the Explicit Name which was placed into the folds of the breastplate. Through the breastplate, they would communicate the answers of Hashem to questions the Kohein asked of Him, hence they would (מֵאִיר), light up and explain their words and וּמְתַּמֵּם) complete their words, i.e. make words come true. (Yoma 73b). This explanation of our Rabbis concerning the translation of keraisi and plaisi can be found in Berachos 4a.

appendix.p: [[9]] I have given to the son of your master. The king is permitted to transfer an estate1 as it is said (Shmuel I, 8:14) Within the jurisdiction of the monarchy is [the power] to take their fields and their vineyards and to give it to his servants.
[[11]] So will your servant do. Mephivoshes will eat at my table. Tsivoh said, “So will your servant do.” And Dovid responded, “Mephivoshes will eat at my table.”2
[[12]] Those who dwelled in the house of Tsivoh. His children and his slaves.3
appendix.ftnote: 1From its previous rightful owner to another person of his choice. This is Rebbe Yosi’s view in Sanhedrin 20b that those royal powers spoken of in Shmuel are to be taken literally as belonging to the king and not just a means of frightening the people into respecting the king which is Rebbe Yehudi’s view there in Sanhedrin, (See also Tosfos, ibid).
2The verse contains the words of two separate speakers, Tzivoh is speaking in the first part of the verse and Dovid responds in the second part.
3Mentioned in verse 10.

appendix.p: [[2]] As his father acted with kindness towards me. And what was the kindness? When Dovid was fleeing because of Shaul, his father, mother and brothers came to [join] him. “Dovid led them before the king of Moav”1 [Dovid] said to him, “Please, [let] my father and mother dwell with you.” [The king of Moav] killed them [all] except for one of them [i.e., the brothers] who fled and escaped to the land of the people of Amon, to Nochosh. This is a Midrash Rebbe Tanchuma in [Parshas] Vayeiroh ailov.
[[3]] Do you think Dovid honors your father. Does it appear in your eyes that Dovid is honoring your father? They are warned, “Do not seek peace with them”,2 and he is seeking peace with you?
[[4]] Their clothes. Their robes.
Their buttocks. The buttocks.
[[16]] Shovach the commander of Hadarezer’s aray. Because he was very mighty and powerful, he is mentioned by name.
appendix.ftnote: 1Shmuel I, 22:4.
2Devorim 23:7. This verse is referring to Amon and Moav mentioned earlier in verse 4.

appendix.p: [[1]] At the time [of year] when kings go forth. There is a time of year when it is the practice that troops go forth, when the land is full of growth and the horses find produce in the field to eat.
[[4]] From her uncleanliness. From her menstrual impurity.
[[6]] Send me Urioh. [Dovid] intendead that he [Urioh] lie with his wife in order that it be thought that from him [Urioh] she was pregnant.
[[8]] The king’s meal. [Yonasan translates:] the king’s meal.1

[[15]] And he will be struck and killed. In order for [Batsheva] to be divorced [from Urioh] retroactively. the result would be that [Dovid] did not cohabit with a married woman. Because all [soldiers] who went out to war wrote a conditional divorce document for their wife should they die in battle.2
[[21]] The son of Yerubeshes. This is Gidon who fought with Boshes, which is the Baal.3
[[25]] Intensity your war [against] the city and destroy it. The words of the message4 [end] at this point.
You should encourage him [Yoav]. Dovid [then] said to the messenger, “Encourage Yoav with consoling words so that his heart should not weaken.
appendix.ftnote: 1Dovid sent men with provisions for Urioh to be eaten at his home.

2Rashi in Kesubos 9b gives this same explanation. Tosafos there explains that Rashi means that the condition was not necessarily that the soldier dies, but even if he does not return at the end of the war, the divorce would be valid.
3See Shoftim 6:32. The name יְרֻבֶּשֶׁת is a contraction of the two words, יָרֶב and בָשֶת, fighting with Boshes. Avimelech’s death, referred to here, is related in Shoftim 9:53.
4From Dovid to Yoav.

appendix.p: [[4]] A traveler came. [Noson] compared the evil inclination at first to a sojourner that is [quickly] going on his way. Afterwords he is compared to a guest that has become a resident and afterwords he is compared to a man who is the owner of the house.1
Is worthy of death. Someone who steals from a poor person is tantamount to taking his life2 as it is said, “He has taken it’s owner’s life.”3
[[6]] Pay fourfold. This is what [eventually] happened, he was punished with [problems concerning] four children the child4 and Amnon Tomor and Avsholom.5
[[8]] Your master’s woman. Michal, the daughter of Shaul.
I will add on. I would add on for you.

[[14]] Because you have angered the enemies of Adonoy. This is a euphimism a way [to be] respectable to on High.6 Yonasan translated, Because you have opened up you have opened the mouth of [those] who hate the people of God.
[He became sick.] [This word] denotes sickness.
[[16]] And came to repose and lied on the ground. And came [back] to the house and reposed at night lying on the ground.
[[17]] And he did not eat. [A word] denoting eating like [we find], “I will eat from her hand.”7
[[25]] Because of God. That loved him [Shlomo].8

[[26]] The royal city. There were two enforced walls [of cities] in it, an outside one and an inside one. The outside city was [called] the royal city, and the inside [city] was a fortress and stronghold.9
[[30]] The crown of Malkom. The abomination [idol] of the people of Ammon’s name was Malkom. Denoting [the word] Moleich.10
It was [hung over] Dovid’s head. Itai the Gitite annulled it.11
[[31]] Saw-like utensils, iron threshing utensils and iron axes. They are types of tortures.
Saw-like utensils. A knife serrated with many [sharp] edges bent towards each other.
Threshing utensils. This is a hacked saw full of cuts like “many sharp edges”12 that is called laime (O.F.).
The streets. In the mud of the streets and so Yonason [also] translated: “He dragged them in the streets.”
appendix.ftnote: 1This verse is Noson’s parable alluding to the evil inclination. The visiton is first referred to as הֵלֶךְ, then אׂרֵחַ and finally as an אִישׁ, representing the evil inclination’s ability to take more and more control over its victim’s life.
2See Baba Kama 119a. Stealing a pruta from anyone is tantamount to killing him.
3Mishlei 1:19.
4Related further on in verse 15.
5The events with Amnon, Tomor and Avsholom start in chapter 13.
6Using “enemies of God” to stand in for God in order for the word “angered” not to have to be applied to Him in a direct way.
7Later, 13:6.
8יֽדִידְיָה is a concatanation of יֽדִיד, beloved one and יָה, God.
9Yoav left this one for Dovid to conquer as is stated in verse 29.
10מוֹלֶךְ is an idol to whom children were sacrificed.

11This explanation of the verse is stated in Avodah Zoroh 24. It is prohibited for Jews to derive any pleasure from the idols of gentiles. They must be anulled by a gentile, i.e., taken out of the service of idol worship, after which they are permitted to Jews. Itai the Gitite, a gentile, did this to Malkom for Dovid’s sake.
12Shmuel I, 13:21.

appendix.p: [[1]] Avsholom had a pretty sister. That was the daughter of his mother.
[[2]] To [the point of] sickness. Until he became sick.
Because she was a virgin. She was modest [and stayed] in the house and did not go outside therefore,

“It was hidden from the eyes of Amnon… It was covered and hidden from him. What excuse he could seek [in order] to lay with her.1 Similar to “When it is concealed from you”,2 [which] Onkelus translates: “When it is hidden from you.”
[[3]] Smart man. For wickedness.
[[4]] Weak. Weak as [we find] “weak and bad [in] appearance”.3
[[5]] The meal. The meal.
[[8]] She made a paste. She made a paste of flour mixed [it] first into boiling water and afterwords in oil.
[[9]] The pan. The [Onkelus’] translation of Machues is “pan”.4

[[13]] Because he will not keep me from you. I am permitted to you because my mother became pregnant with me when she was still a gentile, pretty woman5 that Dovid took conjugally in war. And someone who has a son or daughter from a gentile handmaid is not considered his child for any legal matter.
[[15]] Amnon hated her. Our Rabbis say she tied a hair for him [in his genital area] and caused him to have a severed organ.6

[[16]] Do not do this thing. Do not do this evil thing of sending [me] away which is worse then the other [evil thing] that you did to me. You raped me and then you added on more evil than that by sending me away.
[[23]] The were shearing. It was there custom to make a party when they sheared their flocks.
[[26]] Will not come with us. If you can not go, let Amnon go with us.
[[32]] This has been Avsholom’s order. By Avsholom’s command was this order bestowed on his servants to kill Amnon.

[[39]] Dovid desired. This is a shortened verse, [it means to say:] “Dovid’s soul desired.” Yonoson also translates [this way:] “Dovid’s soul desired,” as [we find:] “[My Soul] yearns, and even pines.”7 Language [denoting] desire.
Because he was consoled concerning Amnon. He accepted [words of] consolation.
appendix.ftnote: 1According to Rashi, the words in our verse, “because she was a virgin” do not tell us why Amnon was desirous of her. The reason for his desire was because she was pretty. Rashi consequently explains that these words are telling us why she was inaccessible to Amnon and are connected to the words that follow, “it was hidden in the eyes of Amnon” to find a way to lay with her.
2Devorim 17:8.
3Bereishis 41:19.
4Vayikro 6:14.
5The laws concerning the taking of gentile woman during war is discused in Devorim begginning in 21:10. The Torah calls her a יְפַת תּוֹאַר, “pretty woman.”
6One who is so injured is prohibited from marrying a Jewish woman as related in Devorim 23:2. This interpretation of our verse is in Sanhedrin 21a.
7Tehilim 84:3.

appendix.p: [[2]] Yoav sent to Tekuah. Our Rabbis said Because olive oil is found there, therefore wisdom is found there.1
[[5]] In truth, I am a widowed woman. אֲבָל means “In truth.”

[[9]] My master the king, the sin is upon me. This is euphemistic for [the sake of] his honour in other words, “You are rebutting me [by] saying, ‘I will command [someone] concerning you,’ I will [then] go on my way and you will not command [anyone] concerning me, and my son will get murdered. Upon who is this sin?”

[[11]] Please remember Adonoy. God was stringent concerning the distance [necessary] to save lives2 as it is said, “He will overtake him because the way was long”.3 This is [her reference with], “To avoid giving more [time] for the avenger to destroy,” and you are pushing me [away].
[[13]] Why did you think this. You suspected that a Jew could come to kill another [Jew] without witnesses and a warning.

That which the king said he himself is guilty of. This thing that you have decided for others, that you said to me “hair from your son shall not fall to the ground.” Now that I have revealed to you that this thing never happened, but it was only [a parable] to your two sons, do not reverse yourself saying, “I said this mistakingly and I have reconsidered” in order that the king not bring back his son, Avsholom that his been exiled from him and has fled.
The king will say. Aucenon parleter in O.F.

[[14]] We are [all] going to die. And that punishment is sufficent.4 God will not countenance anyone. a man from [avoiding] death. Therefore the king should devise means to avoid having his exiled one remain an outcast.
[[15]] And now I came to speak to my master, the king these words. As a parable about myself and my son
Because the people frightened me. They frightened me [away] from imploring my master concerning [the plight of] his son lest he become angry with me.
Your handmaiden said, “I will speak.” In this way [with a parable], perhaps he will take action etc.
[[16]] When the king hears [and agrees] to save his handmaiden from the [avenger] man’s hand. who is coming to kill my son and to remove us both from the inheritance [given by] God.5

[[17]] Your handmaiden says. Now that the king has ordered [remedial action] concerning me, his word should provide relief for my son because he will not back away from his kind decision6 because my master, the king is like an angel of God and anger and hatred will not change his kind decision.
[[19]] It is impossible. [This is] like “if it is possible” or like “is it possible” So too [we find] “Is there in the house of a wicked person”7 meaning “is there”.8
[[20]] In order to skirt around. To skirt around [the issue] until the matter concerning the king’s son comes to light.
[But] my master is wise. and you understood that this is coming from Yoav.
[[30]] Which is near me. Near my domain in a place where I can inflict damage.
Which is near me. En mains aussi in O.F.
[[32]] [Then] kill me. The king should kill me.
appendix.ftnote: 1Menochos 85a.
2When a person kills accidently, he must go to a city of refuge. These cities should never be too distant from any potential fugitive who may need to go there.
3Devorim 19:5.
4For Avsholom.
5All this is what the woman was conveying in her parable. This was all designed to be tolerable for the king to hear.
6You came to the kind decision to provide relief to my make believe son in the parable. Please don’t change that decision when deliberating about Avsholom who in real-life needs relief.
7Micha 6:10.
8הָאִש is standing in for הֲיֵשׁ which means “is there”.

appendix.p: [[1]] And [an enfourage of] fifty men etc. All of them had their thighs removed and the heals of their feet cut out.1
[[2]] Avsholom rose early. Every morning.
From one of the tribes of Yisroel. From so and so tribe.
[[4]] And I will judge him righteously. [Targum Yonosan translates:] “And I will judge him truthfully.”
[[7]] At the end of forty years. [After] Yisroel had asked Shmuel for a king this rebellion and weakening of the kingdom occurred.2
I would like to go. To Chevron.
And fulfill the vows [of bringing sacrifices] Our Rabbis said, “[Avsholom wanted] to bring lambs from Chevron3 because there, the lambs were fat.”4

[[11]] Invited and leaving in innovence. It is explained in the Yerushalmi tractate of Sotah5 that he [Avsholom] requested of his father that he [Dovid] write [a document] for him that any two people that he request go with him, should go. He [proceeded] to show it [the document] to two people here and afterwords to two other people and in this way to many.6
[[17]] Far away. [Targum Yonasan translates:] “in a far away place.”
[[18]] By him. Near him, He stood in place and they passed by.
[[19]] With the king. With Avsholom.
Because you are a foreigner. We are fleeing without provisions and food, and because you are a foreigner you will not find people that will have pity on you.

And even if you are estranged [from Avsholom]. And even if you are exiled from the king [Avsholom] because you do not want to be with him, then return to your home because it is not good to go with me because you [just] came yesterday.7

[[20]] And should I today cause you to move with us. I have no place that I can settle you there to escape because I am going to where circumstances have me go each day. When I hear that the pursuers are here I flee here. And so Yonasan translates [the verse], “And if you are estranged [from Avsholom] you can go home” [as:] “And if you you are estranged go [back] to your city.”
I will consider it kindness and truth. I will credit you the favor of kindness and truth that you have done for me.
[[22]] “Go and pass” Together with the rest of the people now that you do not want to part from me.
[[23]] And all the people were passing. From the king and onwards according to his location they are called passers by.8
[[24]] They set down. Like, “They stopped,”9 [Yonasan translates:] “They stopped the Ark.” They stood it off to one side and the people passed by because Dovid wanted it brought with him.
And Evyosor went off [to the side] until [all the people] finished etc. This is a shortened verse they set down the Ark of God until all the people finished travelling.10

Evyosor went off [to the side]. That day he was removed from the Kohanite service.11 because He inquired of the Urim and Tumim but was not answered,12 Tzodok then replaced him. This is what we learned in Seder Olam in tractate Yuma.13
[[27]] If you see this [as right]. I you see this as a good idea, “return to the city etc.
Your two sons with you. It will be in their power to inform me what they hear in the king’s palace. And based on what they inform me I can escape.
[[30]] The heights of Mount Olives. On Mount Olives.
Was covered. “Covered” in the manner of mourners.
Covered. [Yonasan translates:] “Covered.”
[[31]] Dovid was told [by an informer]. Dovid was told by the informer.
Ruin. Ruin as we find “The tool talks too much”.14
[[32]] Arrived at the summit. At the mountain’s summit.

Where he used to bow down to Elokim. Where he used to bow down. When he used to come to Yerusholoyim he would see from that [vantage] point the tent in which the Ark was [placed] and he would bow down.
[[34]] Previously, I was your father’s servant. This is like [saying], Previously I was your father’s servant. It is a verse that [must be] cut.15
[[37]] Was going to come to Yerosholoyim. Started thinking about coming to Yerusholoyim.16
appendix.ftnote: 1Sanhedrin 21a. Rashi there explains that not having thighs enabled them to run faster and not having heels enabled them to step on sharp objects without any sensation of pain.

2This is the opinion of Rebe Nehuroi in the name of Rebbe Yohoshua brought in Temurah 14b. Rashi is explaining that these forty years are not describing how long Avsholom was engaged in his intriguing against the king. Rather, the verse is informing us that forty years after their improper request, the kingdom was weakened.
3Ibid.
4Rashi there brings the Talmud in Menachos 87a that discusses the quality of the lambs of Chevron.
5Chapter 1, halach 8.
